Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TKS-J131-DYRV-44BR-00000-00Apple CEO endorses EU's tougher data privacy regulations2018-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B002Apple CEO endorses EU's tougher data privacy regulations

BRUSSELS - The head of Apple on Wednesday endorsed tough privacy laws for both Europe and the U.S. and renewed the technology giant's commitment to protecting personal data, which he warned was being "weaponized" against users. Speaking at an international conference on data privacy, Apple CEO Tim Cook applauded European Union authorities for bringing in a strict new data privacy law in May and said the iPhone maker supports a U.S. federal privacy law . Cook's speech, along with video comments from Google and Facebook top bosses, in the European Union's home base in Brussels, underscores how the U.S. tech giants are jostling to curry favor in the region as regulators tighten their scrutiny. Data protection has become a major political issue worldwide, and European regulators have led the charge in setting new rules for the big internet companies.

The EU's new General Data Protection Regulation, or GDPR, requires companies to change the way they do business in the region, and a number of headline-grabbing data breaches have raised public awareness of the issue. "In many jurisdictions, regulators are asking tough questions. It is time for rest of the world, including my home country, to follow your lead," Cook said. "We at Apple are in full support of a comprehensive federal privacy law in the United States," he said, to applause from hundreds of privacy officials from more than 70 countries. In the U.S., California is moving to put in regulations similar to the EU's strict rules by 2020 and other states are mulling more aggressive laws. That's rattled the big tech companies, which are pushing for a federal law that would treat them more leniently. Cook warned that technology's promise to drive breakthroughs that benefit humanity is at risk of being overshadowed by the harm it can cause by deepening division and spreading false information. He said the trade in personal information "has exploded into a data industrial complex." "Our own information, from the everyday to the deeply personal, is being weaponized against us with military efficiency," he said. "This is surveillance. And these stockpiles of personal data serve only to enrich the companies that collect them," he said. "This should make us very uncomfortable. It should unsettle us." Cook's appearance was one-up on his tech rivals and showed off his company's credentials in data privacy, which has become a weak point for both Facebook and Google. That is helped by the fact that Apple makes most of its money by selling hardware like iPhones instead of ads based on user data.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TDG-4711-JCT2-K3FT-00000-00Apple CEO expresses doubts about data collection2018-10-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisPg. A11Apple CEO expresses doubts about data collection

Apple chief executive Tim Cook urged consumers not to believe the dominant tech industry narrative that the data collected about them will lead to better services.

In an interview with "Vice News Tonight" that aired Tuesday, Cook highlighted his company's commitment to user privacy, positioning Apple's business as one that stands apart from tech giants that compile massive amounts of personal data and sell the ability to target users through advertising.

"The narrative that some companies will try to get you to believe is: I've got to take all of our data to make my service better," he said. "Well, don't believe them. Whoever's telling you that, it's a bunch of bunk."

Cook's remarks come at a pivotal time for Silicon Valley. In the past year, technology companies and their executives have come under unprecedented scrutiny from elected officials and regulators stemming from a variety of issues, including a barrage of data privacy scandals, accusations of toxic corporate culture, the negative impact of tech platforms on political debate, and concerns over tech overuse and addiction. In recent months, growing calls from Capitol Hill have boosted the prospects of new legislation aimed at big tech companies.

Last week, Facebook disclosed that hackers stole information that could have allowed them to compromise over 50 million user accounts.

The massive data breach was yet another blow to Facebook's reputation, as the company is still reeling from its Cambridge Analytica crisis, and from its role in a Russia-backed misinformation campaign designed to influence the 2016 presidential election.

The top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, Sen. Mark R. Warner of Virginia, called the breach "deeply concerning" and repeated his calls for Congress to pass new data privacy laws.

Just days before the breach was announced, members of Congress questioned representatives from Google, Twitter and several telecom companies regarding user privacy. The companies were largely unwilling to commit to specific privacy rules and instead pledged to work with the Senate Commerce Committee on a comprehensive national privacy law.

Cook said in the interview that he is "exceedingly optimistic" that the topic of data privacy has reached an elevated level of public debate. "When the free market doesn't produce a result that's great for society you have to ask yourself what do we need to do. And I think some level of government regulation is important to come out on that." !@COPYRIGHT=© 2018 The Daily Gleaner (Fredericton)

urn:contentItem:60JT-CFP1-DY2T-F2F8-00000-00Apple CEO joins billionaire club2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. NP9Apple CEO joins billionaire clubAnders Melin and Tom MetcalfBloomberg

Nine years after Steve Jobs stepped down and thrust Tim Cook to the top of Apple Inc., the company is more valuable than ever - and so is Cook.

Apple's share price rose almost 5 per cent last week, leaving the company Jobs co-founded 44 years ago in his parents'California home on the cusp of stock-market milestone: a market value of nearly US$2 trillion.

It was valued at about US$350 billion when Jobs died. Cook, meantime, has joined one of the most elite clubs for CEOs who didn't actually found the companies they run: his net worth has eclipsed US$1 billion, according to calculations by the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

Cook's net worth estimate is based on an analysis of regulatory filings and applying the market performance of a typical wealthy investor to his proceeds from share sales. Cook, 59, said in 2015 that he plans to give most of his fortune away and has already gifted million of dollars worth of Apple shares. His wealth could be lower if he's made other undisclosed charitable gifts.

Josh Rosenstock, a spokesman for Apple, declined to comment.

"This tech cycle has been way bigger and longer than I thought," said Hussein Kanji, a partner at venture capital firm Hoxton Ventures who expressed caution about Apple's long-term outlook after Jobs left the company. "Out of all these stocks, Apple has become the greatest cash generation machine in history."

Apple's market value and Cook's riches reflect the rise of the FAANG stocks, a phrase that didn't even exist in the Jobs era. It also comes as Cook and his fellow Big Tech CEOs - Jeff Bezos of Amazon.com Inc., Sundar Pichai of Alphabet Inc. and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook Inc. - face antitrust investigations into what their critics characterize as monopolistic powers.

While Bezos and Zuckerberg have huge stakes in the companies they founded, Cook's path to the 10-figure-club was more incremental.

The vast majority of his estimated wealth comes from equity awards he's received since joining Apple in 1998, where he has drawn plaudits for mastering the company's complex supply chain.

He got a massive award of restricted shares on his first day as CEO. The equity has paid out in annual increments, with part of them contingent on Apple's stock outperforming at least two-thirds of firms in the S&;P 500. Barring a sudden drop in Apple's stock price, Cook is poised to receive his ninth payout from the award, consisting of 560,000 shares, later this month.

Around half of those will likely be withheld for taxes but the remainder should boost Cook's fortune by another US$100 million. He currently owns 847,969 shares directly, or about 0.02 per cent of Apple shares, worth around US$375 million.

Proceeds from previous share sales, dividends and other compensation add another US$650 million to his net worth, according to calculations by Bloomberg. Apple stock rose 1.6 per cent to US$451.82 in late-afternoon trading on Monday.

Cook's stake is small compared with the mammoth positions founders like Bezos, Zuckerberg and Tesla Inc.'s Elon Musk control at their respective companies. Bloomberg !@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

urn:contentItem:60JT-CFP1-DY2T-F1YW-00000-00Apple CEO joins the billionaire club; Tech company's valuation nears US$2 trillion2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. FP11Apple CEO joins the billionaire club; Tech company's valuation nears US$2 trillionAnders Melin and Tom MetcalfBloomberg

Nine years after Steve Jobs stepped down and thrust Tim Cook to the top of Apple Inc., the company is more valuable than ever - and so is Cook.

Apple's share price rose almost 5 per cent last week, leaving the company Jobs co-founded 44 years ago in his parents'California home on the cusp of stock-market milestone: a market value of nearly US$2 trillion.

It was valued at about US$350 billion when Jobs died. Cook, meantime, has joined one of the most elite clubs for CEOs who didn't actually found the companies they run: his net worth has eclipsed US$1 billion, according to calculations by the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

Cook's net worth estimate is based on an analysis of regulatory filings and applying the market performance of a typical wealthy investor to his proceeds from share sales. Cook, 59, said in 2015 that he plans to give most of his fortune away and has already gifted million of dollars worth of Apple shares. His wealth could be lower if he's made other undisclosed charitable gifts.

Josh Rosenstock, a spokesman for Apple, declined to comment.

"This tech cycle has been way bigger and longer than I thought," said Hussein Kanji, a partner at venture capital firm Hoxton Ventures who expressed caution about Apple's long-term outlook after Jobs left the company. "Out of all these stocks, Apple has become the greatest cash generation machine in history."

Apple's market value and Cook's riches reflect the rise of the FAANG stocks, a phrase that didn't even exist in the Jobs era. It also comes as Cook and his fellow Big Tech CEOs - Jeff Bezos of Amazon.com Inc., Sundar Pichai of Alphabet Inc. and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook Inc. - face antitrust investigations into what their critics characterize as monopolistic powers.

While Bezos and Zuckerberg have huge stakes in the companies they founded, Cook's path to the 10-figure-club was more incremental. The vast majority of his estimated wealth comes from equity awards he's received since joining Apple in 1998, where he has drawn plaudits for mastering the company's complex supply chain.

He got a massive award of restricted shares on his first day as CEO. The equity has paid out in annual increments, with part of them contingent on Apple's stock outperforming at least twothirds of firms in the S&;P 500. Barring a sudden drop in Apple's stock price, Cook is poised to receive his ninth payout from the award, consisting of 560,000 shares, later this month.

Around half of those will likely be withheld for taxes but the remainder should boost Cook's fortune by another US$100 million. He currently owns 847,969 shares directly, or about 0.02 per cent of Apple shares, worth around US$375 million. Proceeds from previous share sales, dividends and other compensation add another US$650 million to his net worth, according to calculations by Bloomberg. Apple stock rose 1.6 per cent to US$451.82 in late-afternoon trading on Monday.

Cook's stake is small compared with the mammoth positions founders like Bezos, Zuckerberg and Tesla Inc.'s Elon Musk control at their respective companies. Apple shares are distributed widely among different investors and executives, so the world's most valuable company has minted very few billionaires among its employees.

When Jobs stepped down in August 2011 and died soon after, Cook had already filled in as interim CEO on several occasions. But investors and analysts were concerned that Apple wouldn't be able to innovate as much as it did in the past.

While Apple over the past decade hasn't revealed a new product as groundbreaking as the iPhone, the company still has thrived. Cook has overseen the development of devices like the iPhone X and Apple Watch, new services like Apple Music, and research on new frontiers like self-driving cars and augmented-reality glasses.

Even the pandemic, which has hammered many other parts of the economy, has been a boon to Apple and other big tech companies as people have gotten even more reliant on their products and services.

Their recent success stands in contrast to the economic upheaval caused by the coronavirus: a growing string of bankruptcies, tens of millions unemployed and massive public deficits.

When Apple reported results recently, Cook acknowledged the hardship facing legions of families and businesses.

"We do not have a zero-sum approach to prosperity," he said on a conference call. "Especially in times like this, we are focused on growing the pie, making sure our success isn't just our success." !@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

David Paul Morris, Bloomberg Files; The latest stock award granted to Tim Cook, chief executive officer of Apple Inc., should boost his fortune by about US$100 million, according to Bloomberg research.;

urn:contentItem:5TDG-4881-JCT2-M2S9-00000-00Apple CEO says giving up your data for better services 'a bunch of bunk'2018-10-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisPg. A12Apple CEO says giving up your data for better services 'a bunch of bunk'

Apple chief executive Tim Cook urged consumers not to believe the dominant tech industry narrative that the data collected about them will lead to better services.

In an interview with "Vice News Tonight" that aired Tuesday, Cook highlighted his company's commitment to user privacy, positioning Apple's business as one that stands apart from tech giants that compile massive amounts of personal data and sell the ability to target users through advertising.

"The narrative that some companies will try to get you to believe is: I've got to take all of our data to make my service better," he said. "Well, don't believe them. Whoever's telling you that, it's a bunch of bunk."

Cook's remarks come at a pivotal time for Silicon Valley. In the past year, technology companies and their executives have come under unprecedented scrutiny from elected officials and regulators stemming from a variety of issues, including a barrage of data privacy scandals, accusations of toxic corporate culture, the negative impact of tech platforms on political debate, and concerns over tech overuse and addiction.

In recent months, growing calls from Capitol Hill have boosted the prospects of new legislation aimed at big tech companies.

Last week, Facebook disclosed that hackers stole information that could have allowed them to compromise over 50 million user accounts. The massive data breach was yet another blow to Facebook's reputation, as the company is still reeling from its Cambridge Analytica crisis, and from its role in a Russia-backed misinformation campaign designed to influence the 2016 presidential election.

The top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, Sen. Mark R. Warner of Virginia, called the breach "deeply concerning" and repeated his calls for Congress to pass new data privacy laws.

Just days before the breach was announced, members of Congress questioned representatives from Google, Twitter and several telecom companies regarding user privacy. The companies were largely unwilling to commit to specific privacy rules and instead pledged to work with the Senate Commerce Committee on a comprehensive national privacy law.

Cook said in the interview that he is "exceedingly optimistic" that the topic of data privacy has reached an elevated level of public debate. "When the free market doesn't produce a result that's great for society you have to ask yourself what do we need to do. And I think some level of government regulation is important to come out on that." !@COPYRIGHT=© 2018 Times &; Transcript (Moncton)

Extracts.SummaryText: Data protection has become a major political issue worldwide, and European regulators have led the charge in setting new rules for the big Internet companies. The EU's new General Data Protection Regulation, or GDPR, requires companies to change the way they do business in the region, and a number of headline-grabbing data breaches have raised public awareness of the issue. urn:contentItem:5TJY-N4Y1-JBM5-R0Y6-00000-00Apple CEO talks tough about privacyCook pushes for stricter data regulations in U.S., applauds EU progress2018-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESSCPg. 3Apple CEO talks tough about privacy
Cook pushes for stricter data regulations in U.S., applauds EU progressKELVIN CHAN

Apple CEO Tim Cook, speaking at a conference in Brussles, said data "is being weaponized against us with military efficiency."STEPHANIE LECOCQ EFE

The head of Apple on Wednesday endorsed tough privacy laws for both Europe and the U.S. and renewed the technology giant's commitment to protecting personal data, which he warned was being "weaponized" against users.

Speaking at an international conference on data privacy, Apple CEO Tim Cook applauded European Union authorities for bringing in a strict new data privacy law in May and said the iPhone maker supports a U.S. federal privacy law.

Cook's speech, along with video comments from Google and Facebook top bosses, in the European Union's home base in Brussels, underscores how the U.S. tech giants are jostling to curry favor in the region as regulators tighten their scrutiny.

Data protection has become a major political issue worldwide, and European regulators have led the charge in setting new rules for the big Internet companies. The EU's new General Data Protection Regulation, or GDPR, requires companies to change the way they do business in the region, and a number of headline-grabbing data breaches have raised public awareness of the issue.

"In many jurisdictions, regulators are asking tough questions. It is time for rest of the world, including my home country, to follow your lead," Cook said.

"We at Apple are in full support of a comprehensive federal privacy law in the United States," he said, to applause from hundreds of privacy officials from more than 70 countries.

In the U.S., California is moving to put in regulations similar to the EU's strict rules by 2020 and other states are mulling more aggressive laws. That's rattled the big tech companies, which are pushing for a federal law that would treat them more leniently.

Cook warned that technology's promise to drive breakthroughs that benefit humanity is at risk of being overshadowed by the harm it can cause by deepening division and spreading false information. He said the trade in personal information "has exploded into a data industrial complex."

"Our own information, from the everyday to the deeply personal, is being weaponized against us with military efficiency," he said. Scraps of personal data are collected for digital profiles that let businesses know users better than they know themselves and allow companies to offer users "increasingly extreme content" that hardens their convictions, Cook said.

"This is surveillance. And these stockpiles of personal data serve only to enrich the companies that collect them," he said. "This should make us very uncomfortable. It should unsettle us."

Cook's appearance was one-up on his tech rivals and showed off his company's credentials in data privacy, which has become a weak point for both Facebook and Google. That is facilitated also by the fact that Apple makes most of its money by selling hardware like iPhones instead of ads based on user data.

"With the spotlight shining as directly as it is, Apple have the opportunity to show that they are the leading player and they are taking up the mantle," said Ben Robson, a lawyer at Oury Clark specializing in data privacy.

His speech comes a week after Apple unveiled expanded privacy protection measures for people in the U.S., Canada, Australia and New Zealand, including allowing them to download all personal data held by Apple. European users already had access to this feature after GDPR took effect. Apple plans to expand it worldwide.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Google head Sundar Pichai sent brief video remarks to the annual meeting of global data privacy chiefs.

Zuckerberg said the social network takes seriously its "basic ethical responsibility" to safeguard personal information but added that "the past year has shown we have a lot more work to do," referring to a big data breach and the scandal over the misuse of data by Cambridge Analytica.

They both said they supported regulation, with Pichai noting Google recently proposed a legislative framework that would build on GDPR and extend many of its principles to users globally.

Chan writes for The Associated Press.

urn:contentItem:5TJT-5MB1-F03R-N463-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook backs privacy laws, warns data being 'weaponized'2018-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook backs privacy laws, warns data being 'weaponized'PTI

Oct 24, 2018( BGR: Your Mobile Life: http://www.bgr.in Delivered by Newstex) The head of Apple on Wednesday endorsed tough privacy laws for both Europe and the US and renewed the technology giant's commitment to protecting personal data, which he warned was being 'weaponized' against users. Speaking at an international conference on data privacy, Apple CEO Tim Cook applauded European Union authorities for bringing in a strict new data privacy law this year and said the iPhone maker supports a US federal privacy law. Cook's remarks, along with comments due later from Google and Facebook top bosses, in the European Union's home base in Brussels, underscore how the US tech giants are jostling to curry favor in the region as regulators tighten their scrutiny.

Data protection has become a major political issue worldwide, and European regulators have led the charge in setting new rules for the big internet companies. The EU's new General Data Protection Regulation, or GDPR, requires companies to change the way they do business in the region, and a number of headline-grabbing data breaches have raised public awareness of the issue. 'In many jurisdictions, regulators are asking tough questions. It is time for rest of the world, including my home country, to follow your lead,' Cook said. 'We at Apple are in full support of a comprehensive federal privacy law in the United States,' he said, to applause from hundreds of privacy officials from more than 70 countries. In the U.S., California is moving to put in regulations similar to the EU's strict rules by 2020 and other states are mulling more aggressive laws. That's rattled the big tech companies, which are pushing for a federal law that would treat them more leniently. Cook warned that technology's promise to drive breakthroughs that benefit humanity is at risk of being overshadowed by the harm it can cause by deepening division and spreading false information. He said the trade in personal information 'has exploded into a data industrial complex.' 'Our own information, from the everyday to the deeply personal, is being weaponized against us with military efficiency,' he said. Scraps of personal data are collected for digital profiles that let businesses know users better than they know themselves and allow companies to offer users increasingly extreme content that hardens their convictions,' Cook said. 'This is surveillance. And these stockpiles of personal data serve only to enrich only the companies that collect them,' he said. Cook's appearance seems set to one-up his tech rivals and show off his company's credentials in data privacy, which has become a weak point for both Facebook and Google. 'With the spotlight shining as directly as it is, Apple have the opportunity to show that they are the leading player and they are taking up the mantle,' said Ben Robson, a lawyer at Oury Clark specializing in data privacy. Cook's appearance 'is going to have good currency,' with officials, he added. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Google head Sundar Pichai were scheduled to address by video the annual meeting of global data privacy chiefs. Only Cook attended in person. He has repeatedly said privacy is a 'fundamental human right' and vowed his company wouldn't sell ads based on customer data the way companies like Facebook do. His speech comes a week after the iPhone maker unveiled expanded privacy protection measures for people in the U.S., Canada, Australia and New Zealand, including allowing them to download all personal data held by Apple. European users already had access to this feature after GDPR took effect in May. Apple plans to expand it worldwide. The International Conference of Data Protection and Privacy Commissioners, held in a different city every year, normally attracts little attention but its Brussels venue this year takes on symbolic meaning as EU officials ratchet up their tech regulation efforts. The 28-nation EU took on global leadership of the issue when it beefed up data privacy regulations by launching GDPR. The new rules require companies to justify the collection and use of personal data gleaned from phones, apps and visited websites. They must also give EU users the ability to access and delete data, and to object to data use. GDPR also allows for big fines benchmarked to revenue, which for big tech companies could amount to billions of dollars. In the first big test of the new rules, Ireland's data protection commission, which is a lead authority for Europe as many big tech firms are based in the country, is investigating Facebook after a data breach let hackers access 3 million EU accounts. Google, meanwhile, shut down its Plus social network this month after revealing it had a flaw that could have exposed personal information of up to half a million people. This is published unedited from the PTI feed.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W8N-4XS1-DXH2-62XW-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook Denies Company is A Monopoly; Xbox Body Wash; Apple Updates Guidelines for Kids' Apps2019-06-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMichael Block, Kurt Knutsson, Jonathan D. WardNEWSFinancial060502cb.231Apple CEO Tim Cook Denies Company is A Monopoly; Xbox Body Wash; Apple Updates Guidelines for Kids' AppsMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Emily Compagno, Newt Gingrich, Judge Andrew Napolitano

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, June 5th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning. We are remembering D-Day, which is tomorrow. President Trump spoke moments ago at the 75th anniversary event in the U.K., reading a prayer originally read by President Franklin D. Roosevelt on the night of June 6th, 1944.

Tariffs on Mexico set to go into effect in five days. Vice President Mike Pence will meet with Mexican officials today at the White House to try to make a deal before that happens.

A rate cut is now on the table officially. Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell said that the central bank could take action if the trade battle escalates. That sparked a huge rally on Wall Street yesterday and that continues this morning.

Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 167 points. That's two-thirds of 1 percent. The S&P is up 20. And the Nasdaq is up 61 as you see.

Next hour we will be getting the may ADP report. The expectation is for 180,000 jobs added to the economy in the month of May.

This after a big rally on Wall Street yesterday on the Powell comments -- take a look. The Dow Industrials finishing up 512 points. That was better than 2 percent. The S&P was up better than 2 percent, 58 points higher. And the Nasdaq up two and two thirds percent. That was 194 points higher on the Nasdaq yesterday. All on the idea that the Fed could in fact cut rates at some point this year.

In Europe this morning, gains there as well. FT 100 is up two thirds of a percent, 44 points. The CAC in Paris is up 36. That's two-thirds of a percent. And the DAX index up 68 points.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed but as you can see, Japan was the best performer, up 1.8 percent on the Nikkei average.

China is hitting Ford Motor now with a fine. What that means for the trade fight coming up.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning.

And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; market strategist at ThirdSeven Advisors Michael Block; and Fox News contributor, attorney Emily Compagno. Great to see everybody this morning.

EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you.

MICHAEL BLOCK, MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRDSEVEN ADVISORS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We've got a lot --

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Can we talk about markets really quickly --

BARTIROMO: Yes, please.

MCDOWELL: -- before we move on to the D-Day commemoration which again is the most important thing.

But in terms of follow through, I'm kind of -- are you surprised that the markets are following through a little bit after the Fed speak yesterday? Because I was listening really closely to what Brian Moynihan was saying, no rate cut this year. But there are a lot of other people -- Barclays, the economists there now think the Fed is going to cut rates by half a percentage point in September. And then another 25 basis point cut later in the year. That's kind of incredible for an economy for the most part that looks really solid right now.

BARTIROMO: It all depends on this trade fight because, you know, we'll see. I mean look what China's doing now. Now, it's messing with Ford Motor. It harassed FedEx last week. It's threatening that it's going to stop the rare earth minerals from getting imported to the U.S. So the fight with China worsens and now we've got this Mexico uncertainty.

BLOCK: Remember, Mr. Moynihan is doing his job as CEO of one of the largest banks in the world, saying everything is going along reasonably well. There's no need to cut rates here.

There's others who are more academic and are saying well, if the unemployment rate is x, then maybe we don't need to cut rates. Remember that James Board (Ph) from the St. Louis fed said the other day, low unemployment rate is not a reason in this situation to not cut rates because there's other things going on.

And then we have a dysfunctional market here. This yield curve is telling us that something is amiss here. We could say this time it's different. We could say it's not a real signal, doesn't matter anymore. The point is, it is affecting the market and the economic psychology out there.

The Fed cutting rates may help alleviate some of that psychosis, if you will, and that's a big part of this.

BARTIROMO: Well, maybe it's sentiment. But I mean look at the actual data points. You've got unemployment at 3.6 percent. We're going to get the ADP number out in a an hour and 10 minutes. And we're expecting to see 180,000 jobs created in the month of May and the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.6 percent.

I recognize the PMI, the purchasing manager's index is showing some weakness certainly on a global basis. And then you have the question, can the U.S. continue growing this way with the rest of the world slowing down? But is it that dire that we need a rate cut?

BLOCK: The rate cut is a matter of instilling confidence and undoing some of the dysfunction in the market. That's the way I look at it. When I talk to professionals, guys who run a lot of money say in the credit sector, they say that the December hike was a mistake. It was done on some backward looking data, and perhaps it shouldn't have been done. This would help undo that.

MCDOWELL: it But it has to be pretty would have to be pretty dire for the fed to cut rates. The only example when it wasn't the case, when it wasn't obvious that a recession was on the horizon or that was real instability in the financial markets was going back to 1995.

I'm just going to send it back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl, thank you.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Apple's push for privacy, the company rolls out a new features to protect children, we've got those details right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Apple quietly making changes after its developer event on Monday. New app store guidelines focus on kids' apps. Joining us now the cyber guy, Kurt Knutsson in L.A. Kurt, good to see you this morning. Tell us what Apple is doing.

KURT KNUTSSON, THE CYBER GUY: Maria, always good to see you. Monday at the big Worldwide Developers Conference just up north of here in San Jose. First of all, thousands of people in attendance, the largest event I've seen so far attended and just after the event they dropped a hidden headline. And that is, that the guidelines for the app store are changing dramatically for app developers that intend to market to kids. Two big things coming out of this.

Number one, no longer will they be able to use third party ads to get to kids. And at the same time, they will not be allowed to use third party trackers. We've seen so much of this in the news more recently, even report it here about the Washington Post experiment where they found that 5,400 trackers were in one person's monthly use of their iPhone when they're not even using their iPhone, they're just simply sending information out. Kid's apps in the past have had trouble with this.

Curious World is one of them coming under fire for sending a child's name, their location, and a lot of other details straight to Facebook, incorporated. And at this point, Apple is saying if you violate these rules, we're really tightening up privacy, you are going to be kicked out of the app store.

COMPAGNO: Kurt, notwithstanding obviously the approval voiced at the Developers Conference, the question I have is whether there was any type of articulated sentiment of why did this take so long?

KNUTSSON: You know, you're not going to hear that in that audience. But you did hear a lot of sort of a relief sighed not on that, but when they talked about -- because they didn't talked about that at the -- at the conference.

What they did talk about is a very related theme and that is the sign-in to Apple feature that will be coming. And that is the ability to use Apple I.D. credentials to sign into other things that we use on a regular basis. The only ones really capitalizing that market is Google and Facebook. Those two going to see some huge competition here, because as Dagen points out, Facebook has just done a splendid job of proving to us that we cannot trust them with our privacy and at the same time, Apple is really embracing despite their occasional hit of the sort of lapses where how come this didn't happen already with regard to this kind of tightening of the app store. The number one rule there is revenue is why that didn't happen.

But the fact of the matter is, they're going to do well in this space. And that's going to be a big improvement for all of us, whether we're talking about our kids or whether we're just talking about our privacy in general, what's left of it, anyway.

BLOCK: Hi Kurt, any indication that say, Alphabet and Amazon are doing similar things in terms of -- you know, guidelines like this?

KNUTSSON: You know, they're typically responsive to Apple in this regard. I think what's going to be interesting is Apple like the sign-in feature as it relates to kids' apps being protected and us just being protected, you're going to see them tighten those rules in that fashion. We haven't heard it yet but at the same time, their credibility is just on a fine line, whether it'd be Alphabet, with Google or you're dealing with Amazon.

Amazon at the same time has become more and more focused on generating revenue from advertisements and not just being a retailer. So we've got our eye on them. But Apple at the same time never takes this information, their big proclamation that market is we're not using your personal data to benefit any other company except for you to interface with us. So, I think Apple is going to do well in the long term with this one.

I think in terms of personally, having covered technology for 20 years, I'm tossing out all the other credentials such as Facebook and Amazon that make it easy to sign on as soon as I have access to what appears to be a much more trusted source.

BARTIROMO: Kurt, thank you. Good to see you.

KNUTSSON: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Kurt Knutsson, joining us there.

Still ahead, jobs in America. The ADP report out for the month of May in about 15 minutes. Next hour, we will have it, right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA, stay with us.

BARTIROMO: : Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, June 5th. Your top stories right now, just before 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning, we are remembering D-day which is tomorrow. President Trump speaking earlier this morning at the 75th anniversary event in the U.K. The formal event ending moments ago with a patriotic fly over.

President Trump also meeting with veterans who fought during the invasion in Normandy. He will be leaving for Ireland later this morning before heading to France.

Tariffs on Mexico sent to go into effect in five days. Vice President Mike Pence will meet with Mexican officials at the White House today to try and make a deal before that happens.

A rate cut is now on the table, Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell says that the central bank could take action if the trade battle escalates.

Markets are rallying this morning on the heels of that comment on top of the big rally yesterday. Dow Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 146 points, two thirds of one percent. S&P is up 15 and the NASDAQ Futures right now up 51.

In just 15 minutes time, we will be getting the ADP report for the month of May. The expectation is --

urn:contentItem:5TFB-T8Y1-DY6F-J25K-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook: Giving up your data for better services is ‘a bunch of bunk'2018-10-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 0Apple CEO Tim Cook: Giving up your data for better services is ‘a bunch of bunk'Hamza Shaban The Washington Post

Apple chief executive Tim Cook urged consumers not to believe the dominant tech industry narrative that the data collected about them will lead to better services. In an interview with "Vice News Tonight" that aired Tuesday, Cook highlighted his company's commitment to user privacy, positioning Apple's business as one that stands apart from tech giants that compile massive amounts of personal data and sell the ability to target users through advertising. "The narrative that some companies will try to get you to believe is: I've got to take all of our data to make my service better," he said.

"Well, don't believe them. Whoever's telling you that, it's a bunch of bunk." Cook's remarks come at a pivotal time for Silicon Valley. In the past year, technology companies and their executives have come under unprecedented scrutiny from elected officials and regulators stemming from a variety of issues, including a barrage of data privacy scandals, accusations of toxic corporate culture, the negative impact of tech platforms on political debate, and concerns over tech overuse and addiction. In recent months, growing calls from Capitol Hill have boosted the prospects of new legislation aimed at big tech companies. Last week, Facebook disclosed that hackers stole information that could have allowed them to compromise over 50 million user accounts. The massive data breach was yet another blow to Facebook's reputation, as the company is still reeling from its Cambridge Analytica crisis, and from its role in a Russia-backed misinformation campaign designed to influence the 2016 presidential election. The top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, Sen. Mark R. Warner of Virginia, called the breach "deeply concerning" and repeated his calls for Congress to pass new data privacy laws. Just days before the breach was announced, members of Congress questioned representatives from Google, Twitter and several telecom companies regarding user privacy. The companies were largely unwilling to commit to specific privacy rules and instead pledged to work with the Senate Commerce Committee on a comprehensive national privacy law. Cook said in the interview that he is "exceedingly optimistic" that the topic of data privacy has reached an elevated level of public debate. "When the free market doesn't produce a result that's great for society you have to ask yourself what do we need to do. And I think some level of government regulation is important to come out on that."

Apple CEO Tim Cook, right, urged consumers in a recent interview not to believe the dominant tech industry narrative that the data collected about them will lead to better services. Bloomberg photo by David Paul Morris

urn:contentItem:5WW0-8XV1-JCMN-Y3Y6-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook mourns the death of Europe's top data cop Giovanni Buttarelli2019-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook mourns the death of Europe's top data cop Giovanni ButtarelliJake Kanter

Aug 21, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) European Data Protection Supervisor Giovanni Buttarelli[1], the European Data Protection Supervisor, has died at the age of 62. Buttarelli was instrumental in overseeing the introduction of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)[2] in Europe. Apple[3] CEO Tim Cook[4] was among those who mourned his death. "Giovanni was a great man, and we are forever in his debt," Cook said.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[5] Apple CEO Tim Cook is among those mourning the surprising death of Giovanni Buttarelli, the European Data Protection Supervisor. Buttarelli, 62, was instrumental in overseeing the introduction of General Data Protection Regulation (or GDPR as it is better known) in Europe last year — laws which look set to reshape the way countries around the world approach privacy. His death was announced by his office on Wednesday[6]. In a statement, it said: It is with the deepest regret that we announce the loss of Giovanni Buttarelli, the European Data Protection Supervisor. Giovanni passed away surrounded by his family in Italy, last night, 20 August 2019. We are all profoundly saddened by this tragic loss of such a kind and brilliant individual. Throughout his life Giovanni dedicated himself completely to his family, to the service of the judiciary and the European Union and its values. His passion and intelligence will ensure an enduring and unique legacy for the institution of the EDPS and for all people whose lives were touched by him. Ciao Giovanni. Buttarelli was among the European officials to welcome Cook to Brussels last year. Cook gave a fiery speech, in which he attacked tech firms like Facebook and Google for hoarding "industrial" amounts of personal data[7]. Read more: EU warns that Facebook's Cambridge Analytica crisis is the 'tip of an iceberg' of data scandals[8] Cook tweeted a picture of Buttarelli on Wednesday, saying: "Heartbroken by the loss of my friend Giovanni Buttarelli, a visionary who advanced the cause of privacy in Europe and around the world. Our thoughts are with his family and all who loved him. Giovanni was a great man, and we are forever in his debt."Tweet Embed: //twitter.com/mims/statuses/1164190339294351360?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw Heartbroken by the loss of my friend Giovanni Buttarelli, a visionary who advanced the cause of privacy in Europe and around the world. Our thoughts are with his family and all who loved him. Giovanni was a great man, and we are forever in his debt. pic.twitter.com/euCLzqc95m[9]Buttarelli, who took up his post as European Data Protection Supervisor in 2014, spoke to Business Insider last year about his concerns around how big tech firms were handling GDPR[10]. He did not name names, but said Silicon Valley companies were "blackmailing" users into agreeing to new data terms ahead of the introduction of the laws.NOW WATCH: How Area 51 became the center of alien conspiracy theories[11]See Also: Amazon is selling Jeffrey Epstein-inspired merchandise, while rivals like eBay and Etsy have removed related products[12]These are the top 32 quarterbacks in the NFL, according to 'Madden 20'[13]Facebook is finally letting users control the info that other websites are sharing with the social network about them[14] SEE ALSO:EU privacy watchdog: Big tech firms urn:contentItem:5TD9-KWJ1-JB4M-V2KK-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook says giving up your data for better services is 'a bunch of bunk';Apple's chief executive said 'some level of government regulation is important to come out' on data privacy.2018-10-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook says giving up your data for better services is 'a bunch of bunk'Apple's chief executive said 'some level of government regulation is important to come out' on data privacy.Hamza Shaban

Apple chief executive Tim Cook urged consumers not to believe the dominant tech industry narrative that the data collected about them will lead to better services.

In an interview with "Vice News Tonight" that aired Tuesday, Cook highlighted his company's commitment to user privacy, positioning Apple's business as one that stands apart from tech giants that compile massive amounts of personal data and sell the ability to target users through advertising.

"The narrative that some companies will try to get you to believe is: I've got to take all of our data to make my service better," he said. "Well, don't believe them. Whoever's telling you that, it's a bunch of bunk."

Cook's remarks come at a pivotal time for Silicon Valley. In the past year, technology companies and their executives have come under unprecedented scrutiny from elected officials and regulators stemming from a variety of issues, including a barrage of data privacy scandals, accusations of toxic corporate culture, the negative impact of tech platforms on political debate, and concerns over tech overuse and addiction. In recent months, growing calls from Capitol Hill have boosted the prospects of new legislation aimed at big tech companies.

Last week, Facebook disclosed that hackers stole information that could have allowed them to compromise over 50 million user accounts. The massive data breach was yet another blow to Facebook's reputation, as the company is still reeling from its Cambridge Analytica crisis, and from its role in a Russia-backed misinformation campaign designed to influence the 2016 presidential election.

The top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, Sen. Mark R. Warner (Va.), called the breach "deeply concerning" and repeated his calls for Congress to pass new data privacy laws.

Just days before the breach was announced, members of Congress questioned representatives from Google, Twitter and several telecom companies regarding user privacy. The companies were largely unwilling to commit to specific privacy rules and instead pledged to work with the Senate Commerce Committee on a comprehensive national privacy law.

Cook said in the interview that he is "exceedingly optimistic" that the topic of data privacy has reached an elevated level of public debate. "When the free market doesn't produce a result that's great for society you have to ask yourself what do we need to do. And I think some level of government regulation is important to come out on that."

urn:contentItem:5XR1-YWY1-JCJY-G1TS-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook says monopolies are not bad as long as they are 'not abused' (but claims the tech giant isn't one anyway)2019-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:3Apple CEO Tim Cook says monopolies are not bad as long as they are 'not abused' (but claims the tech giant isn't one anyway)Chris Dyer For Dailymail.com

Tim Cook has defended the existence of monopolies and said Apple is not one

Apple CEO denied the company is a monopoly after app developers complained

It is accused of anti-competition over App Store and operating system changes

Apple alleged to use privacy protection to block third parties using location data

Tim Cook has defended monopolies in business, saying it is not a problem as long as their position is not abused.

He also said whether firms are overstepping the mark should be decided by regulators and not CEOs.

However, he denied that Apple had a monopoly in any sector, despite accusations to the contrary from app developers.

In July, it was announced the Department of Justice had opened a sweeping antitrust investigation of big technology companies to look at whether their online platforms have hurt competition, suppressed innovation or otherwise harmed consumers.

Cook told the Nikkei Asian Review: 'A monopoly by itself isn't bad if it's not abused.

'The question for those companies is, do they abuse it? And that is for regulators to decide, not for me to decide.'

Cook was being asked about Apple's competition, which in smartphones are Huawei and Samsung Electronics.

Its Macbook is struggling to gain market share in the personal computer sector and its Apple TV+ has recently been launched into a saturated video streaming market.

Cook said: 'We probably have more competitors than any company on earth.'

He also said the sector Apple had the biggest impact was in healthcare, as Apple Watches monitor the user's heart-rate.

Apple's dominance in the mobile phone market have considered many lawmakers to consider them to exert unfair influence, but with the rise of Samsung and Huawei in China, their market position has shrunk in recent years.

Investigations by the DOJ of the big tech platforms - Facebook Inc, Alphabet Inc's Google, Amazon.com Inc and Apple Inc - are expected to be completed next year.

The move came as a growing number of lawmakers called for stricter regulation or even breaking up of the big tech companies, which have come under intense scrutiny following a series of scandals that compromised users' privacy.

Apple was also accused of anti-competitive behavior last month when the company announced new changes to its mobile phone operating system iOS 13, offering a host of new privacy and security features.

US lawmakers involved in the giant antitrust probe into Silicon Calley tech giants warned of their concerns that Apple is using privacy protection as a smokescreen for 'anti-competitive conduct'.

Before the announced changes, app developers could request background tracking permission from users, which is critical for apps that require location services to work, such as Bluetooth apps that help you find your keys like Tile and Trackr.

Critics point to the fact that these applications will essentially no longer be able to function as intended due to the proposed privacy changes.

However, Apple's own tracking features, which are notoriously difficult to opt out of, aren't affected by the change, leading to accusations Apple is trying to hinder third-party developers.

One specific accusation came from music-streaming service Spotify, which filed a legal complaint with the European Commission in March accusing Apple of anti-competitive behavior.

Spotify was unhappy with a 30 per cent fee that Apple charges on App Store subscriptions, arguing Spotify would have to raise its prices to account for the levy.

But Cook denied the company was a monopoly and added that their existence are not necessarily a bad thing.

Cook also said Apple was committed to boosting manufacturing in the US.

He added: 'We've created well over 2 million jobs in the US. The glass on this iPhone is made by Corning in Kentucky. Several of the semiconductors in the iPhone are made in the United States.

'There's enormous manufacturing happening in the US, just not the assembly of the final product.'

Earlier this week when disusing the DOJ probe, Attorney General William Barr cited his previous work for Verizon Communications, in arguing that big companies provided some benefits to consumers, particularly in telecommunications.

He said: 'Big is not bad. I think in certain network industries you can be too Balkanized and no one has the scale necessary for the kind of innovation that we're seeing.'

Apple spokesperson Trudy Muller claims the company is working with developers to address these concerns of seven app developers who wrote to Cook in August.

urn:contentItem:5XR0-FSX1-F03R-N51F-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Monopolies Aren't Actually Bad If They're 'Not Abused'2019-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook Says Monopolies Aren't Actually Bad If They're 'Not Abused'Christopher Baugh

Dec 11, 2019( iPhone in Canada: http://www.iphoneincanada.ca/ Delivered by Newstex) Are all monopolies bad? Apple CEO Tim Cook doesn't seem to think that's the case, as evidenced by comments made in a recent interview.Axios on HBOIn a new interview withNikkei Asian Review[1], Cook touched on a range of familiar topics like privacy, manufacturing, and health.

When talking about antitrust and the fact that regulators are taking a stronger stance against big tech as a whole, however, Cook pushed back, saying that it is the responsibility of the company to not abuse its power. Apple, Cook stresses, sets itself apart from many of the companies under scrutiny because of its commitment to user privacy. 'A monopoly by itself isn't bad if it's not abused,' explained Cook. 'The question for those companies is, do they abuse it? And that is for regulators to decide, not for me to decideit's very important to realize that tech itself and these large tech companies are not monolithicyou're not our product, that's very clear in our minds. We don't believe in trafficking your data.' Cook went on to insist that Apple is not a monopoly, a notion he's repeated for the large part of his tenure as CEO, despite the Cupertino company having weathered numerous complaints of anti-competitive behavior from companies that compete with its services. Apple's App Store has been the subject of inquiries in countries around the world over whether it's a monopoly. Critics say that the App Store is fully controlled by Apple and only accessible on the company's platforms. Most importantly, in order to generate revenue off Apple's App Store, developers, some of which are Apple competitors, need to share the revenue with the tech giant. Spotify became the most recent example of one of these companies by filing a legal complaint with the European Commission in March. Cook's point clearly shows that there's at least some precedent for believing that not all monopolies are bad, even if there's a sense among some people that they are. Needless to say, Apple's monopoly problems aren't going away anytime soon. And Tim Cook's comments might not help to address that. urn:contentItem:5XPT-T5N1-JBG6-5005-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook says monopolies aren't bad if they aren't abused (AAPL)2019-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook says monopolies aren't bad if they aren't abused (AAPL)cwood@businessinsider.com (Charlie Wood)

In an interview with Nikkei Asian Review on Wednesday, the Apple CEO denied that Apple itself has a monopoly in any sector.

REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque

Apple CEO Tim Cook has defended the existence of monopolies in business, saying that "a monopoly by itself isn't bad if it's not abused."

Cook made the remark in a wide-ranging interview with Nikkei Asian Review on Wednesday, while denying that Apple itself has a monopoly in any sector.

Apple has faced several complaints about how its App Store treats app providers who compete with Apple services. This includes one by music streaming firm Spotify, which filed an antitrust complaint with European regulators in March.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

Apple CEO Tim Cook has defended the existence of monopolies in business, while also denying that Apple has a monopoly in any sector.

In an interview with Nikkei Asian Review in Tokyo on Wednesday, during which Cook discussed a range of topics including Apple's treatment of competitors, he said: "A monopoly by itself isn't bad if it's not abused." 

"The question for those companies is, do they abuse it? And that is for regulators to decide, not for me to decide."

Cook insisted Apple itself is not a monopoly - a line he has maintained for the duration of his tenure, despite Apple having faced multiple anti-competition complaints from app providers who compete with its services.

In March, the music streaming service Spotifyfiled a legal complaint with the European Commission over alleged anti-competitive practices.

Reuters

Spotify was unhappy with the 30% fee that Apple charges on App Store subscriptions, arguing that as Apple makes life extremely difficult for services that try and avoid that fee, Spotify would have to raise its prices to account for the levy.

In turn, that would make Spotify more expensive than Apple's in-house streaming service, Apple Music, which doesn't have to pay the same 30% levy.  Cook's reaction to the complaint was to insist that "no reasonable person" would call Apple a monopoly. 

In Wednesday's Nikkei interview, Cook also denied that big tech firms are "monolithic" and attempted to distance Apple from fellow tech giants Facebook and Google, which have both been accused of accumulating consumer data to create near-monopolies.

"You're not our product, that's very clear in our minds. We don't believe in trafficking your data," he said.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

VARNEY: Not me.

MCDOWELL: Not at all. But doing T.V. is, and Stuart is coming up in about 10 minutes' time every Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Stuart Varney 9:00 a.m. Eastern. Thank you, Stuart, great to see you, my friend.

Coming up, a tale two of cities, why New York City's Mayor is backing Amazon's decision to set up shop in the Big Apple, and the hand-outs and perks Amazon got. But no Wal-Mart. Guess why, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Headquarter headache, Amazon facing fallout over its big move to New York City from people all over the political spectrum. Lauren Simonetti has the latest. Hey, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, Dagen, didn't you know that some big businesses are good and others are bad? Well, at least that's the rationale merging from New York City's winning bid for Amazon's second headquarters or part of it. Mayor Bill de Blasio bring up his efforts to keep Wal-Mart out in response while on a local radio program on Friday. This is what he said, "I was actively involved in the effort to keep Wal-Mart out of New York City. Wal-Mart is an entirely different universe in terms of the systematic efforts they've taken to undermine labor, small business, the environment, American workers, and obviously, the politics of the Walton family. Wal-Mart does not belong in New York City."

Yes, he's rolling out the red carpet for Amazon, though, which also doesn't support unions, which also kills off mom and pops, and hasn't put his money where CEO Jeff Bezos' politics are or at least where the politics of his newspaper at The Washington Post are. Whereas this was interesting, I did some research on this, Wal-Mart's Walton family has given money to democratic politicians in the past including the Governor of New York Andrew Cuomo. But let's get back to basics, he was played by Steve Carell, must-see T.V. This was "Saturday Night Live" watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARELL: Some folks have speculated that I was somehow trolling President Trump by building one headquarters in his hometown of Queens, and the other in his current residence of Washington D.C., thereby overshadowing or humiliating them, but that's simply not true. Sure, he attacked me repeatedly on Twitter, but I chose our new locations because they were ideal for growing business, not just to make Donald Trump think about how I'm literally 100 times richer that he is.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: It was awesome. I love the part where they put up all the Twitter attacks. You know, the SNL writers only knew the dog codenames that he -- that the company gave for the 20 finalists competing for the second quarters. Crystal City, Virginia or Arlington (INAUDIBLE) New York (INAUDIBLE) so the Amazon is very dog-friendly. They basically gave each of the cities a dog name for their codename.

MCDOWELL: But by -- can we go back to the de Blasio thing. Because you don't like -- you don't actually like the perks, the tax perks that New York City got, but in terms of the politics, no company helps lower-income Americans more than a Wal-Mart, and giving people easy access to very inexpensive goods and groceries, so they are on par with Amazon.

FREEMAN: Yes, thank God -- thank goodness Mr. de Blasio is not running the country. This idea that I'm going to treat businesses differently because I don't like the politics of their owners, this is -- this is the New York Model, it's keep taxes very high, and no businesses would want to come here, so then decide particular businesses that you like to give big incentives to. There, just lower rates for everybody.

MCDOWELL: Mayor Pothole will never be President Pothole.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Lauren Simonetti, thank you.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Freeman, Carter, thank you.

CARTER: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: It's all about Mr. Varney, Stuart Varney. Take it away, Stuart.

VARNEY: Oh, thank you so much. Good morning, Dagen.

END

urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D53G-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In Race2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

And a magical weekend at the box office, the Fantastic Beasts sequel duking it out with The Grinch in theaters. We'll tell you who took the top spot.

All that and so much more coming up this morning.

Our very own Susan Li from the Fox Business Network. "The Wall Street Journal" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: So it was James talking before the show started on Florida's settle. We got Griff Jenkins coming up in about six, seven minutes from now with a hit from Florida.

Close call election, the Editorial Page wrote about it this morning, but Rick Scott is the Senator from Florida.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right. So that's a Republican pick up.

And I think good for the country that the losers in that race have now conceded. You hate to have a replay of that 2000 drama where it becomes a battle of lawyers.

And this one, fortunately, was decided by voters.

MCDOWELL: Right. And also -- but it does kind of set the stage for two years from now. Can Florida get its act together?

FREEMAN: Yes. I -- this has been going on forever. You look at especially in Palm Beach, I think 2002, '04, '06, 2016, and then earlier this summer with the primary continuing problems following the law.

And I would say high-time for the state government to prioritize performance or --

MCDOWELL: And there is, and we'll get to this as well, but the Broward Country Election Chief, there's -- there are reports out there that Brenda Snipes has resigned amid the recount effort down in Florida.

So we will discuss that. I'll give you a breath to let you collect your thoughts.

FREEMAN: Yes. You know, I think what you want is maybe some legislation at the state level as well because you recall Snipes' predecessor wasn't so hot either, got fired for similar problems.

So, I think you need some kind of standard.

MCDOWELL: She was initially selected by Governor Jeb Bush in --

FREEMAN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- in the early 2000s.

So we'll get -- we'll get into that whole story, but we want to get to -- he said regulation, but we're talking about a different type of regulation.

Coming to big tech, Apple CEO Tim Cook issuing a warning on what he believes to be the inevitable arrival of regulation in Silicon Valley.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: Generally speaking, I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market, but we have to admit when the free market's not working and it hasn't worked here.

And I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Susan, your reaction to that.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I would say it's easy for Tim Cook to say, isn't it? Because he doesn't deal when it comes to data as other people like the Facebook and social media players.

So, some would say that he's probably able to lob stones at glasshouses at this point, and, you know, with him looking at regulation over social media, doesn't that help his position as well?

Doesn't it strengthen Apple at this point? So, I think it's easy for him to say.

MCDOWELL: They've used that certainly as a marketing too, James, but what do you make of this? Because, again, it's possible -- we've talked about this for -- literally I've been talking about it for years, that they need to come up with some sort of self-regulatory system within technology.

But now that you've had these -- Facebook, Google, falling flat on their face, not doing a great job if they even decided to show up in front of Congress that this is a really tricky situation that technology companies are facing.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think Susan raises a great question, is -- I think consumers should be very skeptical here. Is this a play where he thinks his business model will do better under regulation --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

FREEMAN: -- than say a Facebook or a Google that Apple competes with in some arenas?

Yes, Apple has a services business, but they are a hardware company, maybe he sees an advantage.

I just -- I just think this statement that this is a market failure, first of all, markets don't have to work perfectly, they just have to work better than government.

And second of all --

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- people want free services. So, to say it's a failure that people have tolerated years and years of trading personal information for lots of services, I is a mistake.

I think people, for better or worse, have enjoyed a lot of the free stuff they've gotten from Silicon Valley, and, you know, maybe they'd like a different trade.

But I don't think that government --- I'd be very worried about a government program that ends up advantaging incumbents, like Apple, as it - -

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- usually does and prevents new competitor.

MCDOWELL: Well, I had this conversation with someone who works in the technology industry over the last five years days or so about the New York Times article about Facebook.

And the individual's response was, "Grab a drink. Welcome to the party."

LI: Yes, it's not --

MCDOWELL: "Where have you been the last -- "

LI: Not a surprise for anybody, really.

MCDOWELL: " -- the last 10 years of Facebook's life, literally.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That Facebook -- if you used Facebook over the years, they constantly ask you for more and more and more granular personal information about yourself.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And then you sit and go, "Wow, it's free."

LI: Well, I mean there's a -- there's a great article in "The Wall Street Journal" over the weekend.

FREEMAN: You're (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: What do you think is happening?

LI: Yes, that says basically the reason Instagram founders left is because Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg, he wanted to extract more information from you for -- from Instagram.

They wanted to know your location and the Instagram founders are like, "Whoa, whoa, whoa, this is not what we signed up for."

But I think inevitability, that is the -- basically the signal from all of tech.

I was at the Laguna Beach, WSJ --

MCDOWELL: Right. Right.

LI: -- D Live event and --

FREEMAN: Uh-hmm.

LI: -- everybody understands that this is a new reality.

CARTER: Right.

LI: If you don't, if you're not prepared for it, you shouldn't be CEO.

CARTER: But I also think that, you know, if you look at what's happening in Europe, too, a lot of people are saying, "You know what, with privacy, with all of these kinds of concerns out there, we're going that way. We better be prepared for it."

And Tim Cook is in a unique position to talk about privacy because let's not forget, Apple has had a hard line on what privacy means and how you're not going to access anything that's on there, you know, on there.

So I think they think this is going to make them more popular because they are all about privacy and everybody else in social media maybe isn't, so.

LI: I don't know that they're all about privacy willingly, let's just put it that way.

But I think they see this as a -- probably a position of strength that they're in right now.

MCDOWELL: She's referring to the Apple -- and I was very critical of Apple pushing back on the FBI when --

LI: San Bernardino?

MCDOWELL: Yes, when the FBI wanted Apple to help. Essentially right code so they could access the -- one of the terrorists, the murderer's phones and Apple pushed back on that in the courts.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And I was critical of them, but again that was the line.

And this is really -- this is a stance that Steve Jobs took from the very beginning.

But these are different -- they are different businesses.

CARTER: Very different.

MCDOWELL: Facebook and Google are different -- well, Google, to a lesser extent --

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- because of the Android operating system.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And they're in the device business indirectly, but again, it's - - Tim Cook is throwing some shade.

FREEMAN: Yes. Just -- and it could be just a business model question. Ii think you ought to be skeptical when you hear it as -- presented as simply a fundamental belief.

These companies have different models and some of them are more vulnerable to certain regulation than others.

LI: Yes.

FREEMAN: So, I would say consumer beware.

Big tech, big government deal I think is not in our interest.

MCDOWELL: I want to get Susan's reaction to this really quickly.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Apple suppliers are reportedly facing trouble with lower than expected demand for the new iPhones.

Apple's decision to offer more models, part of the problem.

The Wall Street Journal reporting that it's rippling into the supply chain, suppliers are suffering, is this a bigger problem for the -- tech for the - -for Apple?

LI: I think it's a reality that the demand for the new iPhones is not as robust as expected, so Lumentum, Qorvo. These are some of the names I've downgraded now.

Their revenue forecast for the year because they're not expecting as many orders coming from Apple, and this isn't first time that Apple's had problems with launching a new handset.

Remember, the iPhone 5c, do you remember? The cheaper iPhone that they launched five years ago.

MCDOWELL: Right.

LI: A month later, they also cut become on their orders as well because it wasn't selling as well.

I think it's a -- it's a reality that there's saturation in the market. People have the Apples and the handsets that they need.

Can you keep selling 200 million plus each and every year?

MCDOWELL: And then that separate chipmaker, the graphics chipmaker, NVIDIA, it entered a bear market almost in one day.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Has -- it was down 19 percent.

LI: But they've had that track record, up crash, up crash over the last ten years.

MCDOWELL: They have.

I want to move on to American and Chinese trade tensions boiling over at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit.

China reportedly upset of the wording of a phrase they viewed as unfairly singling out their trade practices.

This was the first time in the summit's nearly three-decade history in which the parties did not issue a communique. James, your reaction to this.

How much should we read into this issue? Again, it made the front page of "The Wall Street Journal". Oh, boy. "Summit Breaks Amid Trade Tensions."

FREEMAN: Yes. Yes. When you want to say that you're going to fight protectionism and unfair trade practices, I don't know why anybody would object to that as a goal.

So, maybe this says a little something about the good faith or lack therefore that they are bringing to these upcoming discussions.

MCDOWELL: We will dig into that because it has -- potentially has an immediate market reaction because you saw last week what the market did on just hopes that there's a bright --
