DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: The futures are under pressure this morning, coming off a week of losses, an 85-point loss on the Dow futures. The selling picking up a little bit of steam as we move closer to the opening bell a little more than two and-a-half hours from now.

This after a week of red for all your major market indicators. Dow and Nasdaq falling more than 2 percent last week. The S&P down 1.6 percent.

In Europe we had a little bit of buying earlier in the session. But now the CAC 40 in France and the DAX have dipped into negative territory.

Asian markets finishing higher overnight. All four major markets there to the plus side.

Trouble for Nissan, Japan's NHK reporting that chairman Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. The automaker looking to remove him as chairman.

And a rough road for Apple, CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation but he says it is coming anyway. The tech giant already struggling with orders for its new iPhones. Suppliers are paying the price. We break down all of that for you.

And leaving the crew -- why the CEO J Crew is leaving the company ahead of the holiday season after only being in the position for a little more than a year.

Here with me this morning: Fox Business' Susan Li, along with "Wall Street Journal" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, and pollster and Maslansky & Partners president Lee Carter. Welcome, one and all. What's on your mind?

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Well, this trade issue where the Chinese will not -- the Chinese government, I should say -- will not even agree to the idea that we shouldn't have unfair trade practices. We've seen how in the past they've refused to acknowledge intellectual property theft. Now they're not even willing to endorse as a general principle that we ought to have open, fair trading relationship. Very bizarre.

But maybe it's just setting the table. Maybe this is art of the deal and then they'll be more reasonable later. I don't know.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: But I'm scare when you're using the term "cold war". This is a new cold war and it's been opened in 2018. And they're calling chaos at APEC. I mean they've never seen this before. And it's usually a friendly display of relations between all the countries.

So this is something that President Trump and the administration is shaking up. And we'll see how it works.

MCDOWELL: Let me just raise this issue though, what is better -- acting like everyone gets along and essentially lying? Like oh, we love each other.

FREEMAN: Yes.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: Isn't that what diplomacy is?

MCDOWELL: Or actually like let's crack this egg and just show the world what's really going on.

CARTER: Right. I think it's really fascinating too that people are willing to be patient with this process. American and Chinese trade tensions spilling over -- we were talking about this. Economic giants sparring at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit. China reportedly upset over the wording of a phrase they viewed as unfairly singling out their trade practices. This is the first time in the summit's nearly three-decade history in which a communique was not issued.

Here now, former White House communications director, SkyBridge Capital founder, author of "The Blue Collar President" -- Anthony Scaramucci --

ANTHONY SCARAMUCCI, FOUNDER, SKYBRIDGE CAPITAL: Practicing my APEC wave here.

MCDOWELL: -- no. If you're going to do the wave, we need to teach you the -- it's the light bulb, it's screwing in the light bulb. There you go.

SCARAMUCCI: Good, good. I need shoulder surgery. But go ahead. I'm sorry.

MCDOWELL: Your reaction -- China, the United States. Where do we go from here in terms of the trade relationship?

SCARAMUCCI: So I'm going to say something outrageous. I actually think that they're going to get a deal done pretty quickly. And if it's not next week, it will be before the end of the year because that's the President's personality.

And if you go back to the Canadian-Mexican deal, and you look at the concessions that were made that were minor concessions. And so this has typically been the President's style.

He is very rough in the beginning. He comes out guns a-blazing. He's boxing away. If you read "The Art of the Deal", that's exactly what he does. And then he tries to meet in the middle towards the end of the negotiation.

And so here's another thing for the President. I know his personality well enough to know that he wants this thing done by latest the end of January because he's got to set up the narrative going into the back half of his administration that he's tied up these trade deals. And then he'll want to work on an immigration or an infrastructure deal with the Democrats.

LI: So Anthony I hosted APEC in 2014 and my sources are telling me --

SCARAMUCCI: Were you doing this?

LI: Well, you know, working on it, at great risk. Great risk --

(CROSSTALK)

LI: -- because of it. But basically from my sources in Asia, they said that they were insulted that President Trump didn't even make the trip to Papua New Guinea. So that was already, you know, laying the ground work by not showing respect.

And that might may be a good negotiating tactic as well because at least you're sending a message to the rest of Asia, particularly China, aren't you?

SCARAMUCCI: Well, I mean -- you know, that could be. I think it's a combination of different things. Just the unbelievable schedule that he had leading up into the midterms. I think that they probably held him back from going to Asia.

But I don't really think that should be something that should be insulting anybody. I think what, you know, the Americans are upset about are the IP situation with China and so it appears that there are going to be concessions made there on behalf of the U.S. and so that's where I think the trade deal gets done. But I don't think anybody should be upset that he didn't make it to APEC.

FREEMAN: Ok. So we've talked a lot about the President's time line. And this is really good news that this is not going to be sort of a permanent fight with the Chinese in your view. That he's looking to wrap it up.

How about on the Chinese side? There's this sense that China thinks in decades or centuries but I think there's some pressure on Xi Jinping to deal as well.

SCARAMUCCI: I absolutely think that. If you know where their market is Jim, and you look at where the currency is right now, both of those things are true. And I think one of the things that gets overstated by the western media is the overall strength of the Chinese economy.

Like, if you look at their level three assets, if you're a banking analyst and you're examining their level three assets, it's really the core of the capital structure of the Chinese commercial banking system, they never wrote down those assets after 2008.

And so those assets are wildly overstated which has a big impact on the Chinese government. It puts pressure on their reserves as they try to prop up those banks. And what you don't want is a material slowdown where you see the GDP of China dipping below 6.5 percent because that puts them in a danger zone as it relates to the mass urbanization that's taking place throughout China.

So I absolutely think this is pressure on both sides and I think that the President likes -- I think both presidents like each other. So my guess is this thing will get done. If not next week, shortly thereafter.

I have to say that Theresa May's handling of the Brexit negotiations have been absolutely disastrous. In effect, it's really been a surrender to the European Union. And the proposal that she has put forward is completely unacceptable. It, basically, makes Britain subservient to the European Union; it does not take Britain outside of the E.U. Customs Union, the U.K. will not able to sign free trade agreements including with the United States. GARDINER: Well, Brexit definitely taking place on March 29, 2019. It's a matter of what kind of Brexit it is. That was the key message from the voted leave campaign, the official campaign to vote to leave the European Union.

And so, the British people want to see their sovereignty restored. Theresa May's deal does not deliver that; it's far better, I think, for Britain to -- either renegotiate this new May proposal or seek a "no" deal Brexit where Britain trades with the rest of the world under WTO terms also trades with E.U. under WTO terms. It would be far preferable, I think, to what Theresa May is offering which is a deal that shackles Britain indefinitely to the European Union, that's not what British people voted for.

GARDINER: Well, certainly there are, you know, some supporters of Theresa May within the conservative party. There are also, I think, big business interests who have backed the Theresa May proposal. You would have to confiscate every dollar of adjusted growth income from the top five percent and that would only pay for Medicare for all and these protests kind of speak to that.

GARDINER: Yes, I think, you know, French people have had enough of, you know, huge state taxes and, you know, France has been basically, sort of, a big government, sort of, economic you know, basket case for successive decades thanks to, you know, to high tax policies. urn:contentItem:5W9Y-5J01-DY0W-44YF-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In Race2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

And a magical weekend at the box office, the Fantastic Beasts sequel duking it out with The Grinch in theaters. We'll tell you who took the top spot.

All that and so much more coming up this morning.

Our very own Susan Li from the Fox Business Network. "The Wall Street Journal" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: So it was James talking before the show started on Florida's settle. We got Griff Jenkins coming up in about six, seven minutes from now with a hit from Florida.

Close call election, the Editorial Page wrote about it this morning, but Rick Scott is the Senator from Florida.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right. So that's a Republican pick up.

And I think good for the country that the losers in that race have now conceded. You hate to have a replay of that 2000 drama where it becomes a battle of lawyers.

And this one, fortunately, was decided by voters.

MCDOWELL: Right. And also -- but it does kind of set the stage for two years from now. Can Florida get its act together?

FREEMAN: Yes. I -- this has been going on forever. You look at especially in Palm Beach, I think 2002, '04, '06, 2016, and then earlier this summer with the primary continuing problems following the law.

And I would say high-time for the state government to prioritize performance or --

MCDOWELL: And there is, and we'll get to this as well, but the Broward Country Election Chief, there's -- there are reports out there that Brenda Snipes has resigned amid the recount effort down in Florida.

So we will discuss that. I'll give you a breath to let you collect your thoughts.

FREEMAN: Yes. You know, I think what you want is maybe some legislation at the state level as well because you recall Snipes' predecessor wasn't so hot either, got fired for similar problems.

So, I think you need some kind of standard.

MCDOWELL: She was initially selected by Governor Jeb Bush in --

FREEMAN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- in the early 2000s.

So we'll get -- we'll get into that whole story, but we want to get to -- he said regulation, but we're talking about a different type of regulation.

Coming to big tech, Apple CEO Tim Cook issuing a warning on what he believes to be the inevitable arrival of regulation in Silicon Valley.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: Generally speaking, I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market, but we have to admit when the free market's not working and it hasn't worked here.

And I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Susan, your reaction to that.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I would say it's easy for Tim Cook to say, isn't it? Because he doesn't deal when it comes to data as other people like the Facebook and social media players.

So, some would say that he's probably able to lob stones at glasshouses at this point, and, you know, with him looking at regulation over social media, doesn't that help his position as well?

Doesn't it strengthen Apple at this point? So, I think it's easy for him to say.

MCDOWELL: They've used that certainly as a marketing too, James, but what do you make of this? Because, again, it's possible -- we've talked about this for -- literally I've been talking about it for years, that they need to come up with some sort of self-regulatory system within technology.

But now that you've had these -- Facebook, Google, falling flat on their face, not doing a great job if they even decided to show up in front of Congress that this is a really tricky situation that technology companies are facing.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think Susan raises a great question, is -- I think consumers should be very skeptical here. Is this a play where he thinks his business model will do better under regulation --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

FREEMAN: -- than say a Facebook or a Google that Apple competes with in some arenas?

Yes, Apple has a services business, but they are a hardware company, maybe he sees an advantage.

I just -- I just think this statement that this is a market failure, first of all, markets don't have to work perfectly, they just have to work better than government.

And second of all --

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- people want free services. So, to say it's a failure that people have tolerated years and years of trading personal information for lots of services, I is a mistake.

I think people, for better or worse, have enjoyed a lot of the free stuff they've gotten from Silicon Valley, and, you know, maybe they'd like a different trade.

But I don't think that government --- I'd be very worried about a government program that ends up advantaging incumbents, like Apple, as it - -

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- usually does and prevents new competitor.

MCDOWELL: Well, I had this conversation with someone who works in the technology industry over the last five years days or so about the New York Times article about Facebook.

And the individual's response was, "Grab a drink. Welcome to the party."

LI: Yes, it's not --

MCDOWELL: "Where have you been the last -- "

LI: Not a surprise for anybody, really.

MCDOWELL: " -- the last 10 years of Facebook's life, literally.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That Facebook -- if you used Facebook over the years, they constantly ask you for more and more and more granular personal information about yourself.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And then you sit and go, "Wow, it's free."

LI: Well, I mean there's a -- there's a great article in "The Wall Street Journal" over the weekend.

FREEMAN: You're (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: What do you think is happening?

LI: Yes, that says basically the reason Instagram founders left is because Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg, he wanted to extract more information from you for -- from Instagram.

They wanted to know your location and the Instagram founders are like, "Whoa, whoa, whoa, this is not what we signed up for."

But I think inevitability, that is the -- basically the signal from all of tech.

I was at the Laguna Beach, WSJ --

MCDOWELL: Right. Right.

LI: -- D Live event and --

FREEMAN: Uh-hmm.

LI: -- everybody understands that this is a new reality.

CARTER: Right.

LI: If you don't, if you're not prepared for it, you shouldn't be CEO.

CARTER: But I also think that, you know, if you look at what's happening in Europe, too, a lot of people are saying, "You know what, with privacy, with all of these kinds of concerns out there, we're going that way. We better be prepared for it."

And Tim Cook is in a unique position to talk about privacy because let's not forget, Apple has had a hard line on what privacy means and how you're not going to access anything that's on there, you know, on there.

So I think they think this is going to make them more popular because they are all about privacy and everybody else in social media maybe isn't, so.

LI: I don't know that they're all about privacy willingly, let's just put it that way.

But I think they see this as a -- probably a position of strength that they're in right now.

MCDOWELL: She's referring to the Apple -- and I was very critical of Apple pushing back on the FBI when --

LI: San Bernardino?

MCDOWELL: Yes, when the FBI wanted Apple to help. Essentially right code so they could access the -- one of the terrorists, the murderer's phones and Apple pushed back on that in the courts.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And I was critical of them, but again that was the line.

And this is really -- this is a stance that Steve Jobs took from the very beginning.

But these are different -- they are different businesses.

CARTER: Very different.

MCDOWELL: Facebook and Google are different -- well, Google, to a lesser extent --

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- because of the Android operating system.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And they're in the device business indirectly, but again, it's - - Tim Cook is throwing some shade.

FREEMAN: Yes. Just -- and it could be just a business model question. Ii think you ought to be skeptical when you hear it as -- presented as simply a fundamental belief.

These companies have different models and some of them are more vulnerable to certain regulation than others.

LI: Yes.

FREEMAN: So, I would say consumer beware.

Big tech, big government deal I think is not in our interest.

MCDOWELL: I want to get Susan's reaction to this really quickly.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Apple suppliers are reportedly facing trouble with lower than expected demand for the new iPhones.

Apple's decision to offer more models, part of the problem.

The Wall Street Journal reporting that it's rippling into the supply chain, suppliers are suffering, is this a bigger problem for the -- tech for the - -for Apple?

LI: I think it's a reality that the demand for the new iPhones is not as robust as expected, so Lumentum, Qorvo. These are some of the names I've downgraded now.

Their revenue forecast for the year because they're not expecting as many orders coming from Apple, and this isn't first time that Apple's had problems with launching a new handset.

Remember, the iPhone 5c, do you remember? The cheaper iPhone that they launched five years ago.

MCDOWELL: Right.

LI: A month later, they also cut become on their orders as well because it wasn't selling as well.

I think it's a -- it's a reality that there's saturation in the market. People have the Apples and the handsets that they need.

Can you keep selling 200 million plus each and every year?

MCDOWELL: And then that separate chipmaker, the graphics chipmaker, NVIDIA, it entered a bear market almost in one day.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Has -- it was down 19 percent.

LI: But they've had that track record, up crash, up crash over the last ten years.

MCDOWELL: They have.

I want to move on to American and Chinese trade tensions boiling over at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit.

China reportedly upset of the wording of a phrase they viewed as unfairly singling out their trade practices.

This was the first time in the summit's nearly three-decade history in which the parties did not issue a communique. James, your reaction to this.

How much should we read into this issue? Again, it made the front page of "The Wall Street Journal". Oh, boy. "Summit Breaks Amid Trade Tensions."

FREEMAN: Yes. Yes. When you want to say that you're going to fight protectionism and unfair trade practices, I don't know why anybody would object to that as a goal.

So, maybe this says a little something about the good faith or lack therefore that they are bringing to these upcoming discussions.

MCDOWELL: We will dig into that because it has -- potentially has an immediate market reaction because you saw last week what the market did on just hopes that there's a bright --

LI: They call it chaos at APEC, that's what they're saying in the Asia Pacific right now,

I hosted APEC in 2014, I would say it was very cordial during that session. 2018, four years on, a little bit different.

MCDOWELL: Yes, different president.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That's right.

CARTER: For sure.

MCDOWELL: The recount, meantime, in Florida is over. The final Florida Election results are in. Griff Jenkins is in Lauderdale, Florida, with the very latest.

Good morning, Griff.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS REPORTER: Good morning, Dagen.

You know, after losing 2,000 ballots, missing deadlines, and failing to report accurate numbers on election night, the Broward County Election Supervisor, Brenda Snipes, has reportedly resigned according to the "Sun Sentinel Newspaper."

She is doing that on January 2nd, and now Governor-Elect DeSantis will get to replace her. We'll find out who that will be, but this comes on the heels of really the big news and that is after 18 year in the Senate, Bill Nelson conceding in a video statement to Rick Scott after losing by 10,033 votes.

Here was Nelson's statement, take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL NELSON, FORMER DEMOCRATIC SENATORIAL CANDIDATE: I was not victorious in this race, but I still wish to strongly reaffirm the cause for which we fought. A public office is a public trust.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: That public trust now in the hands of Senator-elect Rick Scott. He pins in an op-ed to Fox News, "Now the voters of Florida have spoken, and I am honored to serve as our state's next senator and share Florida's success with the entire nation."

"With the heated campaign season behind us, it's time for our leads to come together, roll up their sleeves and get something done for families across America. It's time to make Washington work."

In a final note, Dagen, democrats not totally coming up empty. In a recount, they picked up the Commissioner for Agriculture seat, which is a powerful statewide seat. Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Griff.

Griff Jenkins down in Florida. And Griff, hopefully we'll hear from you later in the morning.

One thing I want to bring up really quickly, Lee Carter. Rick Scott won 45 percent of Latino vote in Florida.

CARTER: Wow.

MCDOWELL: He lost his spot by just nine percentage points. House Republicans nationally lost the Latino vote by 40 points. So, that's a very big win for the Republicans and Florida.

CARTER: It's a --

MCDOWELL: And it's a testament to what needs to happen in two years if the Republicans want to keep the leadership.

CARTER: It's a very big win in a -- in a state that has a lot of immigration, too, and a lot of the Hispanic population.

So I think that's something to look at, too, what's so different there.

MCDOWELL: Right. Exactly.

So -- and by the way, we should point out Rick Scott had a Spanish language website and adds up in Spanish. Nelson had neither.

CARTER: Oh.

MCDOWELL: That was according to some of the -- I think reporting from "Bloomberg."

Just to give them credit, "Bloomberg." Give everybody credit.

LI: There you go.

MCDOWELL: There you go.

Coming up, breaking news, Nissan's Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, has reportedly been arrested and questioned in Japan over alleged financial violations.

We'll tell you more about this developing story.

Plus not so fantastic beasts, why the Harry Potter magic didn't deliver expected results at the box office.

A full roundup, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The Chairman of Nissan reportedly under arrest. Cheryl Casone has the details. Good morning, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Big breaking news overnight, Dagen, good morning.

A Japanese T.V. station right now is reporting that Nissan Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, has been now arrested in Tokyo for allegedly violating financial trading law in that country.

Nissan also looks like they are set to remove Ghosn as Chairman after uncovering numerous significant acts of misconduct.

Ghosn, we should also add, is Chairman and Chief Executive of France's Renault.

Shares of Nissan down nearly 10 percent so far this year. This is a breaking story. We'll get you more details as we them into our newsroom.

Now to what's happening back here at home and that devastating wildfire in Northern California.

The search for remains of victims is underway as about 1,000 names remain at a list people unaccounted for.

So far, at least 77 people have been confirmed dead in the Camp Fire.

President Trump visited the area to survey the damage over the weekend, meeting with Governor Brown and Governor-elect Newsom.

Meanwhile, we should add, forecasters say rain could bring some relief for firefighters across Northern California.

But there is a risk of flooding in addition to the good news of the rain.

Well, there was a big winner at the box office over the weekend. A Harry Potter spinoff, but the less than fantastic performance still number one.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EDDIE REDMAYNE: So you're asking me to help hunt him down?

JUDE LAW: I can't move against Grindelwald. It has to be you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The sequel, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald brought in $16 million, but that makes it the lowest total ever for an opening weekend in the Harry Potter franchise.

These movies were spinoff of Harry Potter and it was filmed with 16 percent below their 2016 opening weekend, the first version of this one.

Last week's box office winner, Doctor Seuss' The Grinch brought in just over $38 million.

And rounding up the top five, Bohemian Rhapsody, that's the Queen movie. New release, Instant Family, and Widows rounding out your numbers, Dagen, and those are your headlines. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl.

CASONE: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And I want to ask Susan, and James, and lee about this Carlos Ghosn news because --

LI: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- Susan, you've interviewed him. You understand probably Japanese business practices and law a lot better than most people in business news. So --

LI: Thank you.

Well, yes, I did -- I have interviewed Carlos Ghosn many time and, you know, in Japan, it's a very (INAUDIBLE) domestic market so if you're a foreign CEO and they have found what they call misconduct, which is underreporting, these are allegations of underreporting his salary.

Therefore putting in fraudulent securities documents, they do not take this lightly.

He's also being accused of misusing company funds as well. Renault, of course, taking over Nissan. He only stepped down as CEO last year and I would say that, you know, they do find these allegations to actually be.

There are some, you know, there's evidence to back it up. It's not going to be easy for Carlos Ghosn.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much for that, Susan. We'll discuss that as the morning moves on.

And then this, a teenage Formula Three driver surviving a horrific crash at this weekend's Macau Grand Prix. That story is coming up.

And we check on oil. Oil's steady climb, investors are cautious, but the optimism on the prospect of an OPEC supply cut we'll discuss, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Oil prices recovering today, up about $0.18 a barrel after a historic losing streak.

Still lower, however, after falling to one-year low last week, Maria Bartiromo spoke with Dallas Federal Reserve President, Robert Kaplan, on Friday and he weighed in on the decline.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Is oil an indicator that it is indicating that the global economy is slowing down, you know, or is it just telling us that we've got an oversupply situation?

ROBERT KAPLAN, PRESIDENT, DALLAS FEDERAL RESERVE: There is worry that maybe global demand, especially form emerging markets, will slow a bit.

So, this is why you're seeing the volatility. I would tell you from here I still believe if you go out three to five years, or over the next few years, we're probably in a fragile equilibrium supply-demand.

BARTIROMO: OK.

KAPLAN: You can see a lot of volatility like we've seen, but the fact of the matter is Shell is going to -- is going to need to grow prolifically to keep up with global demand and their limits to how fast Shell can grow.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. OK.

KAPLAN: And so you still may see some price pressure of the upside, but this is why you've seen the short-term downdraft.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now, Former Shell Oil President, John Hofmeister.

Mr. Hofmeister, great to see you. Where do you -- where do you think oil goes from here in the short run?

JOHN HOFMEISTER, FORMER PRESIDENT, SHELL OIL: I think in the short run, it's going to hover around where it is now, Dagen.

I think the waivers on the Iranian sanctions has had a big impact on the traders' mentality as to whether oil is, you know, short or long.

And I -- and I think it's -- there's plenty of oil out there.

I think the Saudis are hard-pressed to really cut production in the aftermath of the Turkey situation.

And I think the Permian Basin has thousands -- not hundreds, but thousands of drill, but uncompleted wells which could come online early next year.

So, I think the -- there's just plenty of supply at the moment.

FREEMAN: John, James Freeman here with The Wall Street Journal. I want to ask you about the Permian. We heard on the show last week that the bottlenecks are largely easing.

Can West Texas producers basically respond and make up for whatever cut the Saudis do manage to persuade on OPEC?

HOFMEISTER: Not in '19, I don't think.

The -- in principle, I agree. The issues, the logistics issues, are being solved with new pipelines, but they're not built yet.

So, they're not in place, but in addition, there are labor shortages that have to be reckoned with and a lot of people are just deferring opportunities in the oil patch for a variety of reasons.

Namely the insecurity that's always been there.

But I do think they will solve those problems and there will be a point at which -- exactly what you said will occur, but I don't think that's in the first half of 2019.

MCDOWELL: Have the steel tariffs cause problems for the pipeline makers?

I know there was some issue about sourcing of the steel used in one particular pipeline.

HOFMEISTER: Well, it's not just the pipeline, it's also the drilling companies or the operating companies because you have all that steel pipe.

And a lot of that pipe has historically come out of China. And so it has played a role, it has increased costs, and, you know, I think people are waiting to see what happens in the larger China-U.S. relationship as to when or how, if ever, that gets fixed.

And the British people in 2016 voted in huge number: 17.4 million Britons voted to leave the European Union; they understood that they were leaving the single market and customs union when they voted. That was the key message from the voted leave campaign, the official campaign to vote to leave the European Union.

And so, the British people want to see their sovereignty restored. Theresa May's deal does not deliver that; it's far better, I think, for Britain to -- either renegotiate this new May proposal or seek a "no" deal Brexit where Britain trades with the rest of the world under WTO terms also trades with E.U. under WTO terms. It would be far preferable, I think, to what Theresa May is offering which is a deal that shackles Britain indefinitely to the European Union, that's not what British people voted for.

CARTER: Is there anyone -- I'm curious, because it was so divided when Brexit was voted on and there were so many people who wanted to say, is there anyone right now who looks at this deal and says, I'm happy that we're not doing a hard exit -- is there any of the constituents here who said this is, this is what we should be doing?

GARDINER: Well, certainly there are, you know, some supporters of Theresa May within the conservative party. There are also, I think, big business interests who have backed the Theresa May proposal. There are also many business leaders who oppose this deal as well. So, certainly, there has been a mixed reaction to this, but if you look at the public opinion polls, there is less than 20 percent support for the Theresa May deal right now. It's deeply unpopular. There's a lack of trust in the prime minister and she's no Margaret Thatcher, Theresa May, that's for sure.

Margaret Thatcher would've negotiated a tough deal in the British national interests. In addition, Theresa May has pledged to hand over 39 billion pounds to European Union for nothing in return. I think the, you know, the British have been treated with utter, you know, disdain and contempt by European Union, and this is a sheer blackmail from the E.U. here and should not give in to these demands.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: So, it sounds like you're not a Theresa May fan, is that fair to characterize you that way? Does she need to go?

GARDINER: I have to say, she's been hugely disappointing and I think if she faces a vote of "no" confidence, there's a very good chance, I think, that we could see a new prime minister by the end of this year.

MCDOWELL: I want to move across the channel to France. Protests erupting over increased taxes on fuel, now what do these protests say about the popularity of Macron's presidency?

GARDINER: Uh, well, I think -- you know, Emmanuel Macron's presidency has been nothing short of disastrous, really. He has an opinion poll rating at around, sort of, 21 percentage points which is not exactly a vote of confidence from the French people. I think that Emmanuel Macron is seen as deeply out of touch, as arrogant, as someone who doesn't understand the concerns of ordinary French voters. He's a politician, I think, he was full of, sort of, you know, grand visionary ideas, that cannot understand, you know, why his own voters don't -- you know, don't support him anymore.

And this latest fuel tax which hits tens of millions of French drivers is deeply unpopular, that's fueling the protests, but Emmanuel Macron, I think, as somebody who really lives in a sort of another, you know, political dimension, who dreams of creating a grand European Union Army while his own people around from the streets protesting against his leadership, so I think there's a lot of delusional thinking, actually, in the Elysee Palace these days under Emmanuel Macron.

MCDOWELL: Nile, this is a conversation I had over the weekend with someone, that the socialists, the kind of new born American socialist that we hear from quite often, they kind of preach that if we just tax the one percent more, we can pay for all of these lovely things that Americans need, but that is not what goes on in other nations, say, across Europe. The people of these nations -- and I look at France, are taxed to their teeth, in the form of gas taxes, you name -- value-added taxes. It's not just the one percent that's paying for if everything.

And in fact, in this country, if you confiscated every single dollar that the top one percent earned in adjusted growth income, it wouldn't be enough money to pay for Medicare for all, it' would be two trillion versus 3.2. trillion. You would have to confiscate every dollar of adjusted growth income from the top five percent and that would only pay for Medicare for all and these protests kind of speak to that.

GARDINER: Yes, I think, you know, French people have had enough of, you know, huge state taxes and, you know, France has been basically, sort of, a big government, sort of, economic you know, basket case for successive decades thanks to, you know, to high tax policies. You know, hundreds of thousands of French citizens have fled to London over the past decade seeking jobs and opportunities in lower taxes, actually and so you've got economic refugees leaving France heading to -- especially to the U.K. where there's a lower tax regime and more free market policies.

And basically, I think, increasing Europeans are rejecting socialist style government -- and at the end of the day, Emmanuel Macron is a big government thinker, he talks about, you know, free trade, he talks about free markets. But in reality, you know, France remains whetted to very high levels of taxation, it has high levels of unemployment; Emmanuel Macron is at heart a protectionist he's someone who calls Brexit a crime. You know, this is a leader who, I think, is just deeply out of touch with, you know, his own -- you know, his own people and I think is the reflection of the huge economic problems that you see across big government high tax European Union today.

MCDOWELL: James, real quick.

FREEMAN: Yes, he -- obviously, Macron came into office promising the opposite: A more dynamic economy.

GARDINER: Yes.

FREEMAN: A more open economy in France, I guess it hasn't happened, exactly.

GARDINER: That is not that -- that is not materialized at all. And in fact, I think, you know, Emmanuel Macron's big priority right now is a creation of some sort of grand European Union super state. So, he is leader of the Euro Federalist in Europe and its latest plan calls to build a European Union Army which he calls -- calls for to challenge the United States. And so, this is the mindset of the, of the French president right now, completely delusional and out of touch with reality altogether. And so, it's hard to see how Emmanuel Macron is going to be re-elected in 2022 at this rate.

MCDOWELL: What are they using baguettes as spears and power of taxation to frighten everyone? Sorry, I couldn't resist. Thank you so much, sir. Great to see you, Nile Gardiner.

GARDINER: Thank you very much.

MCDOWELL: Yes, absolutely. Facebook fallout Mr. Varney, Stuart Varney that is, will weigh in on how the Web site can make people depressed. "Saturday Night Live" poking fun at Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE CARELL, ACTOR: Hi everyone, as you know, Amazon just announced location of its two new headquarters in New York and Virginia. And everyone, except for the people who live there and people who live in all the places we didn't choose, is thrilled.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: More of Steve Carell. We have to say thank you to Susan Li, you'll catch her at the New York Stock Exchange all day. She's working hard, stay with us, Varney straight ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: More fallout for Facebook, CEO Mark Zuckerberg under fire over his reactions to damaging reports about the company. And now, a new study also shows it can make you depressed. Joining me now is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: OK. Actually, there is a new study.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

VARNEY: And it is objective. It's from the University of Pennsylvania. Now, this has got nothing to do with Facebook's data breaches or their, you know, censorship of conservative opinion, this is something completely separate. This is getting used to this new thing, social networks. Well, the University of Pennsylvania studied I think 140, 150 undergraduates at the college, and for some of them, half of them, they took away their social network usage. Then just limited to 10 minutes a day, that half of the study, their mood all improved. No more depression, no more, what -- less depression, less anxiety. The other group which stayed with social networks hours and hours and hours a day, no improvement in mood whatsoever. Apparently, this is the first cause and effect study that's being recognized as Facebook can give you depression.

Now, this occur -- it occurs to me that, you know, younger person, you're on Facebook, and you're scrolling through other people's lives, and all the people's lives on Facebook are always wonderful, great boyfriend, great girlfriend, fabulous family, new job, new house, wonderful vacation on the beach, you got it all. But what about you? You look bad in comparison to all of your friends and relatives who are looking so good on Facebook. So you get depressed because you're not enjoying life like they are. And it's a way -- we have to get used to this thing, it's not going to go away. But, we have to get used to how to use it, and I don't think we're there yet.

MCDOWELL: I stopped using Facebook, and even before that, Stuart, I lied about virtually every bit of information I ever gave them. I am actually 25 years of age according to Facebook whereabouts.

VARNEY: Yes, and I'm 39. You know, that's life, but I -- actually, I don't use Facebook. I don't do it.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You have other -- you're out cutting brush and doing things outdoors, so I can't imagine you ever having time to like scroll through recipes for ooey gooey butter cake on Facebook.

VARNEY: You're absolutely right there, Dagen. And no contest.

MCDOWELL: I just do not see that being your bag, Mr. Varney.

VARNEY: Not me.

MCDOWELL: Not at all. But doing T.V. is, and Stuart is coming up in about 10 minutes' time every Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Stuart Varney 9:00 a.m. Eastern. Thank you, Stuart, great to see you, my friend.

Coming up, a tale two of cities, why New York City's Mayor is backing Amazon's decision to set up shop in the Big Apple, and the hand-outs and perks Amazon got. But no Wal-Mart. Guess why, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Headquarter headache, Amazon facing fallout over its big move to New York City from people all over the political spectrum. Lauren Simonetti has the latest. Hey, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, Dagen, didn't you know that some big businesses are good and others are bad? Well, at least that's the rationale merging from New York City's winning bid for Amazon's second headquarters or part of it. Mayor Bill de Blasio bring up his efforts to keep Wal-Mart out in response while on a local radio program on Friday. This is what he said, "I was actively involved in the effort to keep Wal-Mart out of New York City. Wal-Mart is an entirely different universe in terms of the systematic efforts they've taken to undermine labor, small business, the environment, American workers, and obviously, the politics of the Walton family. Wal-Mart does not belong in New York City."

Yes, he's rolling out the red carpet for Amazon, though, which also doesn't support unions, which also kills off mom and pops, and hasn't put his money where CEO Jeff Bezos' politics are or at least where the politics of his newspaper at The Washington Post are. Whereas this was interesting, I did some research on this, Wal-Mart's Walton family has given money to democratic politicians in the past including the Governor of New York Andrew Cuomo. But let's get back to basics, he was played by Steve Carell, must-see T.V. This was "Saturday Night Live" watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARELL: Some folks have speculated that I was somehow trolling President Trump by building one headquarters in his hometown of Queens, and the other in his current residence of Washington D.C., thereby overshadowing or humiliating them, but that's simply not true. Sure, he attacked me repeatedly on Twitter, but I chose our new locations because they were ideal for growing business, not just to make Donald Trump think about how I'm literally 100 times richer that he is.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: It was awesome. I love the part where they put up all the Twitter attacks. You know, the SNL writers only knew the dog codenames that he -- that the company gave for the 20 finalists competing for the second quarters. Crystal City, Virginia or Arlington (INAUDIBLE) New York (INAUDIBLE) so the Amazon is very dog-friendly. They basically gave each of the cities a dog name for their codename.

MCDOWELL: But by -- can we go back to the de Blasio thing. Because you don't like -- you don't actually like the perks, the tax perks that New York City got, but in terms of the politics, no company helps lower-income Americans more than a Wal-Mart, and giving people easy access to very inexpensive goods and groceries, so they are on par with Amazon.

FREEMAN: Yes, thank God -- thank goodness Mr. de Blasio is not running the country. This idea that I'm going to treat businesses differently because I don't like the politics of their owners, this is -- this is the New York Model, it's keep taxes very high, and no businesses would want to come here, so then decide particular businesses that you like to give big incentives to. There, just lower rates for everybody.

MCDOWELL: Mayor Pothole will never be President Pothole.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Lauren Simonetti, thank you.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Freeman, Carter, thank you.

CARTER: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: It's all about Mr. Varney, Stuart Varney. Take it away, Stuart.

VARNEY: Oh, thank you so much. Good morning, Dagen.

END

Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In Race2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

And a magical weekend at the box office, the Fantastic Beasts sequel duking it out with The Grinch in theaters. We'll tell you who took the top spot.

All that and so much more coming up this morning.

Our very own Susan Li from the Fox Business Network. "The Wall Street Journal" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: So it was James talking before the show started on Florida's settle. We got Griff Jenkins coming up in about six, seven minutes from now with a hit from Florida.

Close call election, the Editorial Page wrote about it this morning, but Rick Scott is the Senator from Florida.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right. So that's a Republican pick up.

And I think good for the country that the losers in that race have now conceded. You hate to have a replay of that 2000 drama where it becomes a battle of lawyers.

And this one, fortunately, was decided by voters.

MCDOWELL: Right. And also -- but it does kind of set the stage for two years from now. Can Florida get its act together?

FREEMAN: Yes. I -- this has been going on forever. You look at especially in Palm Beach, I think 2002, '04, '06, 2016, and then earlier this summer with the primary continuing problems following the law.

And I would say high-time for the state government to prioritize performance or --

Whereas this was interesting, I did some research on this, Wal-Mart's Walton family has given money to democratic politicians in the past including the Governor of New York Andrew Cuomo. But let's get back to basics, he was played by Steve Carell, must-see T.V. This was "Saturday Night Live" watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARELL: Some folks have speculated that I was somehow trolling President Trump by building one headquarters in his hometown of Queens, and the other in his current residence of Washington D.C., thereby overshadowing or humiliating them, but that's simply not true. Sure, he attacked me repeatedly on Twitter, but I chose our new locations because they were ideal for growing business, not just to make Donald Trump think about how I'm literally 100 times richer that he is.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: It was awesome. I love the part where they put up all the Twitter attacks. You know, the SNL writers only knew the dog codenames that he -- that the company gave for the 20 finalists competing for the second quarters. Crystal City, Virginia or Arlington (INAUDIBLE) New York (INAUDIBLE) so the Amazon is very dog-friendly. They basically gave each of the cities a dog name for their codename.

MCDOWELL: But by -- can we go back to the de Blasio thing. Because you don't like -- you don't actually like the perks, the tax perks that New York City got, but in terms of the politics, no company helps lower-income Americans more than a Wal-Mart, and giving people easy access to very inexpensive goods and groceries, so they are on par with Amazon.

FREEMAN: Yes, thank God -- thank goodness Mr. de Blasio is not running the country. This idea that I'm going to treat businesses differently because I don't like the politics of their owners, this is -- this is the New York Model, it's keep taxes very high, and no businesses would want to come here, so then decide particular businesses that you like to give big incentives to. There, just lower rates for everybody.

MCDOWELL: Mayor Pothole will never be President Pothole.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Lauren Simonetti, thank you.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Freeman, Carter, thank you.

CARTER: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: It's all about Mr. Varney, Stuart Varney. Take it away, Stuart.

VARNEY: Oh, thank you so much. Good morning, Dagen.

END

urn:contentItem:5TSP-K701-JBHT-D2PT-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In Race2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

And a magical weekend at the box office, the Fantastic Beasts sequel duking it out with The Grinch in theaters. We'll tell you who took the top spot.

All that and so much more coming up this morning.

Our very own Susan Li from the Fox Business Network. "The Wall Street Journal" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: So it was James talking before the show started on Florida's settle. We got Griff Jenkins coming up in about six, seven minutes from now with a hit from Florida.

Close call election, the Editorial Page wrote about it this morning, but Rick Scott is the Senator from Florida.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right. So that's a Republican pick up.

And I think good for the country that the losers in that race have now conceded. You hate to have a replay of that 2000 drama where it becomes a battle of lawyers.

And this one, fortunately, was decided by voters.

MCDOWELL: Right. And also -- but it does kind of set the stage for two years from now. Can Florida get its act together?

FREEMAN: Yes. I -- this has been going on forever. You look at especially in Palm Beach, I think 2002, '04, '06, 2016, and then earlier this summer with the primary continuing problems following the law.

And I would say high-time for the state government to prioritize performance or --

MCDOWELL: And there is, and we'll get to this as well, but the Broward Country Election Chief, there's -- there are reports out there that Brenda Snipes has resigned amid the recount effort down in Florida.

So we will discuss that. I'll give you a breath to let you collect your thoughts.

FREEMAN: Yes. You know, I think what you want is maybe some legislation at the state level as well because you recall Snipes' predecessor wasn't so hot either, got fired for similar problems.

So, I think you need some kind of standard.

MCDOWELL: She was initially selected by Governor Jeb Bush in --

FREEMAN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- in the early 2000s.

So we'll get -- we'll get into that whole story, but we want to get to -- he said regulation, but we're talking about a different type of regulation.

Coming to big tech, Apple CEO Tim Cook issuing a warning on what he believes to be the inevitable arrival of regulation in Silicon Valley.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: Generally speaking, I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market, but we have to admit when the free market's not working and it hasn't worked here.

And I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Susan, your reaction to that.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I would say it's easy for Tim Cook to say, isn't it? Because he doesn't deal when it comes to data as other people like the Facebook and social media players.

So, some would say that he's probably able to lob stones at glasshouses at this point, and, you know, with him looking at regulation over social media, doesn't that help his position as well?

Doesn't it strengthen Apple at this point? So, I think it's easy for him to say.

MCDOWELL: They've used that certainly as a marketing too, James, but what do you make of this? Because, again, it's possible -- we've talked about this for -- literally I've been talking about it for years, that they need to come up with some sort of self-regulatory system within technology.

But now that you've had these -- Facebook, Google, falling flat on their face, not doing a great job if they even decided to show up in front of Congress that this is a really tricky situation that technology companies are facing.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think Susan raises a great question, is -- I think consumers should be very skeptical here. Is this a play where he thinks his business model will do better under regulation --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

FREEMAN: -- than say a Facebook or a Google that Apple competes with in some arenas?

Yes, Apple has a services business, but they are a hardware company, maybe he sees an advantage.

I just -- I just think this statement that this is a market failure, first of all, markets don't have to work perfectly, they just have to work better than government.

And second of all --

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- people want free services. So, to say it's a failure that people have tolerated years and years of trading personal information for lots of services, I is a mistake.

I think people, for better or worse, have enjoyed a lot of the free stuff they've gotten from Silicon Valley, and, you know, maybe they'd like a different trade.

But I don't think that government --- I'd be very worried about a government program that ends up advantaging incumbents, like Apple, as it - -

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- usually does and prevents new competitor.

MCDOWELL: Well, I had this conversation with someone who works in the technology industry over the last five years days or so about the New York Times article about Facebook.

And the individual's response was, "Grab a drink. Welcome to the party."

LI: Yes, it's not --

MCDOWELL: "Where have you been the last -- "

LI: Not a surprise for anybody, really.

MCDOWELL: " -- the last 10 years of Facebook's life, literally.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That Facebook -- if you used Facebook over the years, they constantly ask you for more and more and more granular personal information about yourself.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And then you sit and go, "Wow, it's free."

LI: Well, I mean there's a -- there's a great article in "The Wall Street Journal" over the weekend.

FREEMAN: You're (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: What do you think is happening?

LI: Yes, that says basically the reason Instagram founders left is because Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg, he wanted to extract more information from you for -- from Instagram.

They wanted to know your location and the Instagram founders are like, "Whoa, whoa, whoa, this is not what we signed up for."

But I think inevitability, that is the -- basically the signal from all of tech.

I was at the Laguna Beach, WSJ --

MCDOWELL: Right. Right.

LI: -- D Live event and --

FREEMAN: Uh-hmm.

LI: -- everybody understands that this is a new reality.

CARTER: Right.

LI: If you don't, if you're not prepared for it, you shouldn't be CEO.

CARTER: But I also think that, you know, if you look at what's happening in Europe, too, a lot of people are saying, "You know what, with privacy, with all of these kinds of concerns out there, we're going that way. We better be prepared for it."

And Tim Cook is in a unique position to talk about privacy because let's not forget, Apple has had a hard line on what privacy means and how you're not going to access anything that's on there, you know, on there.

So I think they think this is going to make them more popular because they are all about privacy and everybody else in social media maybe isn't, so.

LI: I don't know that they're all about privacy willingly, let's just put it that way.

But I think they see this as a -- probably a position of strength that they're in right now.

MCDOWELL: She's referring to the Apple -- and I was very critical of Apple pushing back on the FBI when --

LI: San Bernardino?

MCDOWELL: Yes, when the FBI wanted Apple to help. Essentially right code so they could access the -- one of the terrorists, the murderer's phones and Apple pushed back on that in the courts.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And I was critical of them, but again that was the line.

And this is really -- this is a stance that Steve Jobs took from the very beginning.

But these are different -- they are different businesses.

CARTER: Very different.

MCDOWELL: Facebook and Google are different -- well, Google, to a lesser extent --

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- because of the Android operating system.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And they're in the device business indirectly, but again, it's - - Tim Cook is throwing some shade.

FREEMAN: Yes. Just -- and it could be just a business model question. Ii think you ought to be skeptical when you hear it as -- presented as simply a fundamental belief.

These companies have different models and some of them are more vulnerable to certain regulation than others.

LI: Yes.

FREEMAN: So, I would say consumer beware.

Big tech, big government deal I think is not in our interest.

MCDOWELL: I want to get Susan's reaction to this really quickly.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Apple suppliers are reportedly facing trouble with lower than expected demand for the new iPhones.

Apple's decision to offer more models, part of the problem.

The Wall Street Journal reporting that it's rippling into the supply chain, suppliers are suffering, is this a bigger problem for the -- tech for the - -for Apple?

LI: I think it's a reality that the demand for the new iPhones is not as robust as expected, so Lumentum, Qorvo. These are some of the names I've downgraded now.

Their revenue forecast for the year because they're not expecting as many orders coming from Apple, and this isn't first time that Apple's had problems with launching a new handset.

Remember, the iPhone 5c, do you remember? The cheaper iPhone that they launched five years ago.

MCDOWELL: Right.

LI: A month later, they also cut become on their orders as well because it wasn't selling as well.

I think it's a -- it's a reality that there's saturation in the market. People have the Apples and the handsets that they need.

Can you keep selling 200 million plus each and every year?

MCDOWELL: And then that separate chipmaker, the graphics chipmaker, NVIDIA, it entered a bear market almost in one day.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Has -- it was down 19 percent.

LI: But they've had that track record, up crash, up crash over the last ten years.

MCDOWELL: They have.

I want to move on to American and Chinese trade tensions boiling over at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit.

China reportedly upset of the wording of a phrase they viewed as unfairly singling out their trade practices.

This was the first time in the summit's nearly three-decade history in which the parties did not issue a communique. James, your reaction to this.

How much should we read into this issue? Again, it made the front page of "The Wall Street Journal". Oh, boy. "Summit Breaks Amid Trade Tensions."

FREEMAN: Yes. Yes. When you want to say that you're going to fight protectionism and unfair trade practices, I don't know why anybody would object to that as a goal.

So, maybe this says a little something about the good faith or lack therefore that they are bringing to these upcoming discussions.

MCDOWELL: We will dig into that because it has -- potentially has an immediate market reaction because you saw last week what the market did on just hopes that there's a bright --

LI: They call it chaos at APEC, that's what they're saying in the Asia Pacific right now,

I hosted APEC in 2014, I would say it was very cordial during that session. 2018, four years on, a little bit different.

MCDOWELL: Yes, different president.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That's right.

CARTER: For sure.

MCDOWELL: The recount, meantime, in Florida is over. The final Florida Election results are in. Griff Jenkins is in Lauderdale, Florida, with the very latest.

Good morning, Griff.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS REPORTER: Good morning, Dagen.

You know, after losing 2,000 ballots, missing deadlines, and failing to report accurate numbers on election night, the Broward County Election Supervisor, Brenda Snipes, has reportedly resigned according to the "Sun Sentinel Newspaper."

She is doing that on January 2nd, and now Governor-Elect DeSantis will get to replace her. We'll find out who that will be, but this comes on the heels of really the big news and that is after 18 year in the Senate, Bill Nelson conceding in a video statement to Rick Scott after losing by 10,033 votes.

Here was Nelson's statement, take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL NELSON, FORMER DEMOCRATIC SENATORIAL CANDIDATE: I was not victorious in this race, but I still wish to strongly reaffirm the cause for which we fought. A public office is a public trust.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: That public trust now in the hands of Senator-elect Rick Scott. He pins in an op-ed to Fox News, "Now the voters of Florida have spoken, and I am honored to serve as our state's next senator and share Florida's success with the entire nation."

THERESA MAY, BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: My job is to get the best deal. Parliament must then examine it and do what is in national interest. We have in view a deal that will work for the U.K. and let no one be in any doubt, I am determined to deliver it.

NILE GARDINER, DIRECTOR OF THE THATCHER CENTER FOR FREEDOM AT THE HERITAGE FOUNDATION: Well, good morning. I have to say that Theresa May's handling of the Brexit negotiations have been absolutely disastrous. In effect, it's really been a surrender to the European Union. And the proposal that she has put forward is completely unacceptable. It, basically, makes Britain subservient to the European Union; it does not take Britain outside of the E.U. Customs Union, the U.K. will not able to sign free trade agreements including with the United States. So, this is a deal that does not restore British sovereignty and self-determination and freedom to the British people.

So, Theresa May, I think, has not lived up to the promises she made to the British people earlier. And in many ways, and this is an appalling weak- kneed deal offered by the British prime minister, which is being heavily opposed by a large number of MPs within her party and she's faced a wave of resignations, there'll be more resignations to come. FREEMAN: Nile, James Freeman here with the Wall Street Journal. GARDINER: Well, Brexit definitely taking place on March 29, 2019. It's a matter of what kind of Brexit it is. That was the key message from the voted leave campaign, the official campaign to vote to leave the European Union.

And so, the British people want to see their sovereignty restored. Theresa May's deal does not deliver that; it's far better, I think, for Britain to -- either renegotiate this new May proposal or seek a "no" deal Brexit where Britain trades with the rest of the world under WTO terms also trades with E.U. under WTO terms. It would be far preferable, I think, to what Theresa May is offering which is a deal that shackles Britain indefinitely to the European Union, that's not what British people voted for.

CARTER: Is there anyone -- I'm curious, because it was so divided when Brexit was voted on and there were so many people who wanted to say, is there anyone right now who looks at this deal and says, I'm happy that we're not doing a hard exit -- is there any of the constituents here who said this is, this is what we should be doing?

GARDINER: Well, certainly there are, you know, some supporters of Theresa May within the conservative party. There are also, I think, big business interests who have backed the Theresa May proposal. There are also many business leaders who oppose this deal as well. So, certainly, there has been a mixed reaction to this, but if you look at the public opinion polls, there is less than 20 percent support for the Theresa May deal right now. It's deeply unpopular. You would have to confiscate every dollar of adjusted growth income from the top five percent and that would only pay for Medicare for all and these protests kind of speak to that.

GARDINER: Yes, I think, you know, French people have had enough of, you know, huge state taxes and, you know, France has been basically, sort of, a big government, sort of, economic you know, basket case for successive decades thanks to, you know, to high tax policies.
