urn:contentItem:5W9V-B721-JBHT-D2D0-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In Race2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

And a magical weekend at the box office, the Fantastic Beasts sequel duking it out with The Grinch in theaters. We'll tell you who took the top spot.

All that and so much more coming up this morning.

Our very own Susan Li from the Fox Business Network. "The Wall Street Journal" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: So it was James talking before the show started on Florida's settle. We got Griff Jenkins coming up in about six, seven minutes from now with a hit from Florida.

Close call election, the Editorial Page wrote about it this morning, but Rick Scott is the Senator from Florida.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right. So that's a Republican pick up.

And I think good for the country that the losers in that race have now conceded. You hate to have a replay of that 2000 drama where it becomes a battle of lawyers.

And this one, fortunately, was decided by voters.

MCDOWELL: Right. And also -- but it does kind of set the stage for two years from now. Can Florida get its act together?

FREEMAN: Yes. I -- this has been going on forever. You look at especially in Palm Beach, I think 2002, '04, '06, 2016, and then earlier this summer with the primary continuing problems following the law.

And I would say high-time for the state government to prioritize performance or --

MCDOWELL: And there is, and we'll get to this as well, but the Broward Country Election Chief, there's -- there are reports out there that Brenda Snipes has resigned amid the recount effort down in Florida.

So we will discuss that. I'll give you a breath to let you collect your thoughts.

FREEMAN: Yes. You know, I think what you want is maybe some legislation at the state level as well because you recall Snipes' predecessor wasn't so hot either, got fired for similar problems.

So, I think you need some kind of standard.

MCDOWELL: She was initially selected by Governor Jeb Bush in --

FREEMAN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- in the early 2000s.

So we'll get -- we'll get into that whole story, but we want to get to -- he said regulation, but we're talking about a different type of regulation.

Coming to big tech, Apple CEO Tim Cook issuing a warning on what he believes to be the inevitable arrival of regulation in Silicon Valley.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: Generally speaking, I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market, but we have to admit when the free market's not working and it hasn't worked here.

And I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Susan, your reaction to that.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I would say it's easy for Tim Cook to say, isn't it? Because he doesn't deal when it comes to data as other people like the Facebook and social media players.

So, some would say that he's probably able to lob stones at glasshouses at this point, and, you know, with him looking at regulation over social media, doesn't that help his position as well?

Doesn't it strengthen Apple at this point? So, I think it's easy for him to say.

MCDOWELL: They've used that certainly as a marketing too, James, but what do you make of this? Because, again, it's possible -- we've talked about this for -- literally I've been talking about it for years, that they need to come up with some sort of self-regulatory system within technology.

But now that you've had these -- Facebook, Google, falling flat on their face, not doing a great job if they even decided to show up in front of Congress that this is a really tricky situation that technology companies are facing.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think Susan raises a great question, is -- I think consumers should be very skeptical here. Is this a play where he thinks his business model will do better under regulation --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

FREEMAN: -- than say a Facebook or a Google that Apple competes with in some arenas?

Yes, Apple has a services business, but they are a hardware company, maybe he sees an advantage.

I just -- I just think this statement that this is a market failure, first of all, markets don't have to work perfectly, they just have to work better than government.

And second of all --

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- people want free services. So, to say it's a failure that people have tolerated years and years of trading personal information for lots of services, I is a mistake.

I think people, for better or worse, have enjoyed a lot of the free stuff they've gotten from Silicon Valley, and, you know, maybe they'd like a different trade.

But I don't think that government --- I'd be very worried about a government program that ends up advantaging incumbents, like Apple, as it - -

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- usually does and prevents new competitor.

MCDOWELL: Well, I had this conversation with someone who works in the technology industry over the last five years days or so about the New York Times article about Facebook.

And the individual's response was, "Grab a drink. Welcome to the party."

LI: Yes, it's not --

MCDOWELL: "Where have you been the last -- "

LI: Not a surprise for anybody, really.

MCDOWELL: " -- the last 10 years of Facebook's life, literally.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That Facebook -- if you used Facebook over the years, they constantly ask you for more and more and more granular personal information about yourself.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And then you sit and go, "Wow, it's free."

LI: Well, I mean there's a -- there's a great article in "The Wall Street Journal" over the weekend.

FREEMAN: You're (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: What do you think is happening?

LI: Yes, that says basically the reason Instagram founders left is because Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg, he wanted to extract more information from you for -- from Instagram.

They wanted to know your location and the Instagram founders are like, "Whoa, whoa, whoa, this is not what we signed up for."

But I think inevitability, that is the -- basically the signal from all of tech.

I was at the Laguna Beach, WSJ --

MCDOWELL: Right. Right.

LI: -- D Live event and --

FREEMAN: Uh-hmm.

LI: -- everybody understands that this is a new reality.

CARTER: Right.

LI: If you don't, if you're not prepared for it, you shouldn't be CEO.

CARTER: But I also think that, you know, if you look at what's happening in Europe, too, a lot of people are saying, "You know what, with privacy, with all of these kinds of concerns out there, we're going that way. We better be prepared for it."

And Tim Cook is in a unique position to talk about privacy because let's not forget, Apple has had a hard line on what privacy means and how you're not going to access anything that's on there, you know, on there.

So I think they think this is going to make them more popular because they are all about privacy and everybody else in social media maybe isn't, so.

LI: I don't know that they're all about privacy willingly, let's just put it that way.

But I think they see this as a -- probably a position of strength that they're in right now.

MCDOWELL: She's referring to the Apple -- and I was very critical of Apple pushing back on the FBI when --

LI: San Bernardino?

MCDOWELL: Yes, when the FBI wanted Apple to help. Essentially right code so they could access the -- one of the terrorists, the murderer's phones and Apple pushed back on that in the courts.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And I was critical of them, but again that was the line.

And this is really -- this is a stance that Steve Jobs took from the very beginning.

But these are different -- they are different businesses.

CARTER: Very different.

MCDOWELL: Facebook and Google are different -- well, Google, to a lesser extent --

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- because of the Android operating system.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And they're in the device business indirectly, but again, it's - - Tim Cook is throwing some shade.

FREEMAN: Yes. Just -- and it could be just a business model question. Ii think you ought to be skeptical when you hear it as -- presented as simply a fundamental belief.

These companies have different models and some of them are more vulnerable to certain regulation than others.

LI: Yes.

FREEMAN: So, I would say consumer beware.

Big tech, big government deal I think is not in our interest.

MCDOWELL: I want to get Susan's reaction to this really quickly.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Apple suppliers are reportedly facing trouble with lower than expected demand for the new iPhones.

Apple's decision to offer more models, part of the problem.

The Wall Street Journal reporting that it's rippling into the supply chain, suppliers are suffering, is this a bigger problem for the -- tech for the - -for Apple?

LI: I think it's a reality that the demand for the new iPhones is not as robust as expected, so Lumentum, Qorvo. These are some of the names I've downgraded now.

Their revenue forecast for the year because they're not expecting as many orders coming from Apple, and this isn't first time that Apple's had problems with launching a new handset.

Remember, the iPhone 5c, do you remember? The cheaper iPhone that they launched five years ago.

MCDOWELL: Right.

LI: A month later, they also cut become on their orders as well because it wasn't selling as well.

I think it's a -- it's a reality that there's saturation in the market. People have the Apples and the handsets that they need.

Can you keep selling 200 million plus each and every year?

MCDOWELL: And then that separate chipmaker, the graphics chipmaker, NVIDIA, it entered a bear market almost in one day.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Has -- it was down 19 percent.

LI: But they've had that track record, up crash, up crash over the last ten years.

MCDOWELL: They have.

I want to move on to American and Chinese trade tensions boiling over at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit.

China reportedly upset of the wording of a phrase they viewed as unfairly singling out their trade practices.

This was the first time in the summit's nearly three-decade history in which the parties did not issue a communique. James, your reaction to this.

How much should we read into this issue? Again, it made the front page of "The Wall Street Journal". Oh, boy. "Summit Breaks Amid Trade Tensions."

FREEMAN: Yes. Yes. When you want to say that you're going to fight protectionism and unfair trade practices, I don't know why anybody would object to that as a goal.

So, maybe this says a little something about the good faith or lack therefore that they are bringing to these upcoming discussions.

MCDOWELL: We will dig into that because it has -- potentially has an immediate market reaction because you saw last week what the market did on just hopes that there's a bright --

LI: They call it chaos at APEC, that's what they're saying in the Asia Pacific right now,

I hosted APEC in 2014, I would say it was very cordial during that session. 2018, four years on, a little bit different.

MCDOWELL: Yes, different president.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That's right.

CARTER: For sure.

MCDOWELL: The recount, meantime, in Florida is over. The final Florida Election results are in. Griff Jenkins is in Lauderdale, Florida, with the very latest.

Good morning, Griff.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS REPORTER: Good morning, Dagen.

You know, after losing 2,000 ballots, missing deadlines, and failing to report accurate numbers on election night, the Broward County Election Supervisor, Brenda Snipes, has reportedly resigned according to the "Sun Sentinel Newspaper."

She is doing that on January 2nd, and now Governor-Elect DeSantis will get to replace her. We'll find out who that will be, but this comes on the heels of really the big news and that is after 18 year in the Senate, Bill Nelson conceding in a video statement to Rick Scott after losing by 10,033 votes.

Here was Nelson's statement, take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL NELSON, FORMER DEMOCRATIC SENATORIAL CANDIDATE: I was not victorious in this race, but I still wish to strongly reaffirm the cause for which we fought. A public office is a public trust.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: That public trust now in the hands of Senator-elect Rick Scott. He pins in an op-ed to Fox News, "Now the voters of Florida have spoken, and I am honored to serve as our state's next senator and share Florida's success with the entire nation."

"With the heated campaign season behind us, it's time for our leads to come together, roll up their sleeves and get something done for families across America. It's time to make Washington work."

In a final note, Dagen, democrats not totally coming up empty. In a recount, they picked up the Commissioner for Agriculture seat, which is a powerful statewide seat. Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Griff.

Griff Jenkins down in Florida. And Griff, hopefully we'll hear from you later in the morning.

One thing I want to bring up really quickly, Lee Carter. Rick Scott won 45 percent of Latino vote in Florida.

CARTER: Wow.

MCDOWELL: He lost his spot by just nine percentage points. House Republicans nationally lost the Latino vote by 40 points. So, that's a very big win for the Republicans and Florida.

CARTER: It's a --

MCDOWELL: And it's a testament to what needs to happen in two years if the Republicans want to keep the leadership.

CARTER: It's a very big win in a -- in a state that has a lot of immigration, too, and a lot of the Hispanic population.

So I think that's something to look at, too, what's so different there.

MCDOWELL: Right. Exactly.

So -- and by the way, we should point out Rick Scott had a Spanish language website and adds up in Spanish. Nelson had neither.

CARTER: Oh.

MCDOWELL: That was according to some of the -- I think reporting from "Bloomberg."

Just to give them credit, "Bloomberg." Give everybody credit.

LI: There you go.

MCDOWELL: There you go.

Coming up, breaking news, Nissan's Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, has reportedly been arrested and questioned in Japan over alleged financial violations.

We'll tell you more about this developing story.

Plus not so fantastic beasts, why the Harry Potter magic didn't deliver expected results at the box office.

A full roundup, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The Chairman of Nissan reportedly under arrest. Cheryl Casone has the details. Good morning, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Big breaking news overnight, Dagen, good morning.

A Japanese T.V. station right now is reporting that Nissan Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, has been now arrested in Tokyo for allegedly violating financial trading law in that country.

Nissan also looks like they are set to remove Ghosn as Chairman after uncovering numerous significant acts of misconduct.

Ghosn, we should also add, is Chairman and Chief Executive of France's Renault.

Shares of Nissan down nearly 10 percent so far this year. This is a breaking story. We'll get you more details as we them into our newsroom.

Now to what's happening back here at home and that devastating wildfire in Northern California.

The search for remains of victims is underway as about 1,000 names remain at a list people unaccounted for.

So far, at least 77 people have been confirmed dead in the Camp Fire.

President Trump visited the area to survey the damage over the weekend, meeting with Governor Brown and Governor-elect Newsom.

Meanwhile, we should add, forecasters say rain could bring some relief for firefighters across Northern California.

But there is a risk of flooding in addition to the good news of the rain.

Well, there was a big winner at the box office over the weekend. A Harry Potter spinoff, but the less than fantastic performance still number one.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EDDIE REDMAYNE: So you're asking me to help hunt him down?

JUDE LAW: I can't move against Grindelwald. It has to be you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Is oil an indicator that it is indicating that the global economy is slowing down, you know, or is it just telling us that we've got an oversupply situation?

So, this is why you're seeing the volatility. I would tell you from here I still believe if you go out three to five years, or over the next few years, we're probably in a fragile equilibrium supply-demand.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MEYER: Well, you know, I doubt that she's able to get the President and the Republican Senate to agree to things by doing anything overly dramatic. I think he wants these people to be his opponents and to help rev up his base for 2020. Do I think it's good for our political system, do I think it's good for our markets? Absolutely not, but it's good for President Trump's re-election campaign.

Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In Race2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTLee Carter, John Hofmeister, Ron MeyerNEWSFinancial111901cb.231Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is "Inevitable"; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In RaceDagen McDowell, Susan Li, James Freeman, Griff Jenkins, Cheryl Casone, Jared Max

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

And a magical weekend at the box office, the Fantastic Beasts sequel duking it out with The Grinch in theaters. We'll tell you who took the top spot.

All that and so much more coming up this morning.

Our very own Susan Li from the Fox Business Network. "The Wall Street Journal" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: So it was James talking before the show started on Florida's settle. We got Griff Jenkins coming up in about six, seven minutes from now with a hit from Florida.

Close call election, the Editorial Page wrote about it this morning, but Rick Scott is the Senator from Florida.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right. So that's a Republican pick up.

And I think good for the country that the losers in that race have now conceded. You hate to have a replay of that 2000 drama where it becomes a battle of lawyers.

And this one, fortunately, was decided by voters.

MCDOWELL: Right. And also -- but it does kind of set the stage for two years from now. Can Florida get its act together?

FREEMAN: Yes. I -- this has been going on forever. You look at especially in Palm Beach, I think 2002, '04, '06, 2016, and then earlier this summer with the primary continuing problems following the law.

And I would say high-time for the state government to prioritize performance or --

MCDOWELL: And there is, and we'll get to this as well, but the Broward Country Election Chief, there's -- there are reports out there that Brenda Snipes has resigned amid the recount effort down in Florida.

So we will discuss that. I'll give you a breath to let you collect your thoughts.

FREEMAN: Yes. You know, I think what you want is maybe some legislation at the state level as well because you recall Snipes' predecessor wasn't so hot either, got fired for similar problems.

So, I think you need some kind of standard.

MCDOWELL: She was initially selected by Governor Jeb Bush in --

FREEMAN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- in the early 2000s.

So we'll get -- we'll get into that whole story, but we want to get to -- he said regulation, but we're talking about a different type of regulation.

Coming to big tech, Apple CEO Tim Cook issuing a warning on what he believes to be the inevitable arrival of regulation in Silicon Valley.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: Generally speaking, I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market, but we have to admit when the free market's not working and it hasn't worked here.

And I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Susan, your reaction to that.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I would say it's easy for Tim Cook to say, isn't it? Because he doesn't deal when it comes to data as other people like the Facebook and social media players.

So, some would say that he's probably able to lob stones at glasshouses at this point, and, you know, with him looking at regulation over social media, doesn't that help his position as well?

Doesn't it strengthen Apple at this point? So, I think it's easy for him to say.

MCDOWELL: They've used that certainly as a marketing too, James, but what do you make of this? Because, again, it's possible -- we've talked about this for -- literally I've been talking about it for years, that they need to come up with some sort of self-regulatory system within technology.

But now that you've had these -- Facebook, Google, falling flat on their face, not doing a great job if they even decided to show up in front of Congress that this is a really tricky situation that technology companies are facing.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think Susan raises a great question, is -- I think consumers should be very skeptical here. Is this a play where he thinks his business model will do better under regulation --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

FREEMAN: -- than say a Facebook or a Google that Apple competes with in some arenas?

Yes, Apple has a services business, but they are a hardware company, maybe he sees an advantage.

I just -- I just think this statement that this is a market failure, first of all, markets don't have to work perfectly, they just have to work better than government.

And second of all --

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- people want free services. So, to say it's a failure that people have tolerated years and years of trading personal information for lots of services, I is a mistake.

I think people, for better or worse, have enjoyed a lot of the free stuff they've gotten from Silicon Valley, and, you know, maybe they'd like a different trade.

But I don't think that government --- I'd be very worried about a government program that ends up advantaging incumbents, like Apple, as it - -

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- usually does and prevents new competitor.

MCDOWELL: Well, I had this conversation with someone who works in the technology industry over the last five years days or so about the New York Times article about Facebook.

And the individual's response was, "Grab a drink. Welcome to the party."

LI: Yes, it's not --

MCDOWELL: "Where have you been the last -- "

LI: Not a surprise for anybody, really.

MCDOWELL: " -- the last 10 years of Facebook's life, literally.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That Facebook -- if you used Facebook over the years, they constantly ask you for more and more and more granular personal information about yourself.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And then you sit and go, "Wow, it's free."

LI: Well, I mean there's a -- there's a great article in "The Wall Street Journal" over the weekend.

FREEMAN: You're (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: What do you think is happening?

LI: Yes, that says basically the reason Instagram founders left is because Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg, he wanted to extract more information from you for -- from Instagram.

They wanted to know your location and the Instagram founders are like, "Whoa, whoa, whoa, this is not what we signed up for."

But I think inevitability, that is the -- basically the signal from all of tech.

I was at the Laguna Beach, WSJ --

MCDOWELL: Right. Right.

LI: -- D Live event and --

FREEMAN: Uh-hmm.

LI: -- everybody understands that this is a new reality.

CARTER: Right.

LI: If you don't, if you're not prepared for it, you shouldn't be CEO.

CARTER: But I also think that, you know, if you look at what's happening in Europe, too, a lot of people are saying, "You know what, with privacy, with all of these kinds of concerns out there, we're going that way. We better be prepared for it."

And Tim Cook is in a unique position to talk about privacy because let's not forget, Apple has had a hard line on what privacy means and how you're not going to access anything that's on there, you know, on there.

So I think they think this is going to make them more popular because they are all about privacy and everybody else in social media maybe isn't, so.

LI: I don't know that they're all about privacy willingly, let's just put it that way.

But I think they see this as a -- probably a position of strength that they're in right now.

MCDOWELL: She's referring to the Apple -- and I was very critical of Apple pushing back on the FBI when --

LI: San Bernardino?

MCDOWELL: Yes, when the FBI wanted Apple to help. Essentially right code so they could access the -- one of the terrorists, the murderer's phones and Apple pushed back on that in the courts.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And I was critical of them, but again that was the line.

And this is really -- this is a stance that Steve Jobs took from the very beginning.

But these are different -- they are different businesses.

CARTER: Very different.

MCDOWELL: Facebook and Google are different -- well, Google, to a lesser extent --

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- because of the Android operating system.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And they're in the device business indirectly, but again, it's - - Tim Cook is throwing some shade.

FREEMAN: Yes. Just -- and it could be just a business model question. Ii think you ought to be skeptical when you hear it as -- presented as simply a fundamental belief.

These companies have different models and some of them are more vulnerable to certain regulation than others.

LI: Yes.

FREEMAN: So, I would say consumer beware.

Big tech, big government deal I think is not in our interest.

MCDOWELL: I want to get Susan's reaction to this really quickly.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Apple suppliers are reportedly facing trouble with lower than expected demand for the new iPhones.

Apple's decision to offer more models, part of the problem.

The Wall Street Journal reporting that it's rippling into the supply chain, suppliers are suffering, is this a bigger problem for the -- tech for the - -for Apple?

LI: I think it's a reality that the demand for the new iPhones is not as robust as expected, so Lumentum, Qorvo. These are some of the names I've downgraded now.

Their revenue forecast for the year because they're not expecting as many orders coming from Apple, and this isn't first time that Apple's had problems with launching a new handset.

Remember, the iPhone 5c, do you remember? The cheaper iPhone that they launched five years ago.

MCDOWELL: Right.

LI: A month later, they also cut become on their orders as well because it wasn't selling as well.

I think it's a -- it's a reality that there's saturation in the market. People have the Apples and the handsets that they need.

Can you keep selling 200 million plus each and every year?

MCDOWELL: And then that separate chipmaker, the graphics chipmaker, NVIDIA, it entered a bear market almost in one day.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Has -- it was down 19 percent.

LI: But they've had that track record, up crash, up crash over the last ten years.

MCDOWELL: They have.

I want to move on to American and Chinese trade tensions boiling over at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit.

China reportedly upset of the wording of a phrase they viewed as unfairly singling out their trade practices.

This was the first time in the summit's nearly three-decade history in which the parties did not issue a communique. James, your reaction to this.

How much should we read into this issue? Again, it made the front page of "The Wall Street Journal". Oh, boy. "Summit Breaks Amid Trade Tensions."

FREEMAN: Yes. Yes. When you want to say that you're going to fight protectionism and unfair trade practices, I don't know why anybody would object to that as a goal.

So, maybe this says a little something about the good faith or lack therefore that they are bringing to these upcoming discussions.

MCDOWELL: We will dig into that because it has -- potentially has an immediate market reaction because you saw last week what the market did on just hopes that there's a bright --

LI: They call it chaos at APEC, that's what they're saying in the Asia Pacific right now,

I hosted APEC in 2014, I would say it was very cordial during that session. 2018, four years on, a little bit different.

MCDOWELL: Yes, different president.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That's right.

CARTER: For sure.

MCDOWELL: The recount, meantime, in Florida is over. The final Florida Election results are in. Griff Jenkins is in Lauderdale, Florida, with the very latest.

Good morning, Griff.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS REPORTER: Good morning, Dagen.

You know, after losing 2,000 ballots, missing deadlines, and failing to report accurate numbers on election night, the Broward County Election Supervisor, Brenda Snipes, has reportedly resigned according to the "Sun Sentinel Newspaper."

She is doing that on January 2nd, and now Governor-Elect DeSantis will get to replace her. We'll find out who that will be, but this comes on the heels of really the big news and that is after 18 year in the Senate, Bill Nelson conceding in a video statement to Rick Scott after losing by 10,033 votes.

Here was Nelson's statement, take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL NELSON, FORMER DEMOCRATIC SENATORIAL CANDIDATE: I was not victorious in this race, but I still wish to strongly reaffirm the cause for which we fought. A public office is a public trust.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: That public trust now in the hands of Senator-elect Rick Scott. He pins in an op-ed to Fox News, "Now the voters of Florida have spoken, and I am honored to serve as our state's next senator and share Florida's success with the entire nation."

"With the heated campaign season behind us, it's time for our leads to come together, roll up their sleeves and get something done for families across America. It's time to make Washington work."

In a final note, Dagen, democrats not totally coming up empty. In a recount, they picked up the Commissioner for Agriculture seat, which is a powerful statewide seat. Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Griff.

Griff Jenkins down in Florida. And Griff, hopefully we'll hear from you later in the morning.

One thing I want to bring up really quickly, Lee Carter. Rick Scott won 45 percent of Latino vote in Florida.

CARTER: Wow.

MCDOWELL: He lost his spot by just nine percentage points. House Republicans nationally lost the Latino vote by 40 points. So, that's a very big win for the Republicans and Florida.

CARTER: It's a --

MCDOWELL: And it's a testament to what needs to happen in two years if the Republicans want to keep the leadership.

CARTER: It's a very big win in a -- in a state that has a lot of immigration, too, and a lot of the Hispanic population.

So I think that's something to look at, too, what's so different there.

MCDOWELL: Right. Exactly.

So -- and by the way, we should point out Rick Scott had a Spanish language website and adds up in Spanish. Nelson had neither.

CARTER: Oh.

MCDOWELL: That was according to some of the -- I think reporting from "Bloomberg."

Just to give them credit, "Bloomberg." Give everybody credit.

LI: There you go.

MCDOWELL: There you go.

Coming up, breaking news, Nissan's Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, has reportedly been arrested and questioned in Japan over alleged financial violations.

We'll tell you more about this developing story.

Plus not so fantastic beasts, why the Harry Potter magic didn't deliver expected results at the box office.

A full roundup, next.

MCDOWELL: The Chairman of Nissan reportedly under arrest. Cheryl Casone has the details. Good morning, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Big breaking news overnight, Dagen, good morning.

A Japanese T.V. station right now is reporting that Nissan Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, has been now arrested in Tokyo for allegedly violating financial trading law in that country.

Nissan also looks like they are set to remove Ghosn as Chairman after uncovering numerous significant acts of misconduct.

Ghosn, we should also add, is Chairman and Chief Executive of France's Renault.

Shares of Nissan down nearly 10 percent so far this year. This is a breaking story. We'll get you more details as we them into our newsroom.

Now to what's happening back here at home and that devastating wildfire in Northern California.

The search for remains of victims is underway as about 1,000 names remain at a list people unaccounted for.

So far, at least 77 people have been confirmed dead in the Camp Fire.

President Trump visited the area to survey the damage over the weekend, meeting with Governor Brown and Governor-elect Newsom.

Meanwhile, we should add, forecasters say rain could bring some relief for firefighters across Northern California.

But there is a risk of flooding in addition to the good news of the rain.

Well, there was a big winner at the box office over the weekend. A Harry Potter spinoff, but the less than fantastic performance still number one.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EDDIE REDMAYNE: So you're asking me to help hunt him down?

JUDE LAW: I can't move against Grindelwald. It has to be you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The sequel, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald brought in $16 million, but that makes it the lowest total ever for an opening weekend in the Harry Potter franchise.

These movies were spinoff of Harry Potter and it was filmed with 16 percent below their 2016 opening weekend, the first version of this one.

Last week's box office winner, Doctor Seuss' The Grinch brought in just over $38 million.

And rounding up the top five, Bohemian Rhapsody, that's the Queen movie. New release, Instant Family, and Widows rounding out your numbers, Dagen, and those are your headlines. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl.

CASONE: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And I want to ask Susan, and James, and lee about this Carlos Ghosn news because --

LI: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- Susan, you've interviewed him. You understand probably Japanese business practices and law a lot better than most people in business news. So --

LI: Thank you.

Well, yes, I did -- I have interviewed Carlos Ghosn many time and, you know, in Japan, it's a very (INAUDIBLE) domestic market so if you're a foreign CEO and they have found what they call misconduct, which is underreporting, these are allegations of underreporting his salary.

Therefore putting in fraudulent securities documents, they do not take this lightly.

He's also being accused of misusing company funds as well. Renault, of course, taking over Nissan. He only stepped down as CEO last year and I would say that, you know, they do find these allegations to actually be.

There are some, you know, there's evidence to back it up. It's not going to be easy for Carlos Ghosn.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much for that, Susan. We'll discuss that as the morning moves on.

And then this, a teenage Formula Three driver surviving a horrific crash at this weekend's Macau Grand Prix. That story is coming up.

And we check on oil. Oil's steady climb, investors are cautious, but the optimism on the prospect of an OPEC supply cut we'll discuss, next.

MCDOWELL: Oil prices recovering today, up about $0.18 a barrel after a historic losing streak.

Still lower, however, after falling to one-year low last week, Maria Bartiromo spoke with Dallas Federal Reserve President, Robert Kaplan, on Friday and he weighed in on the decline.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Is oil an indicator that it is indicating that the global economy is slowing down, you know, or is it just telling us that we've got an oversupply situation?

ROBERT KAPLAN, PRESIDENT, DALLAS FEDERAL RESERVE: There is worry that maybe global demand, especially form emerging markets, will slow a bit.

So, this is why you're seeing the volatility. I would tell you from here I still believe if you go out three to five years, or over the next few years, we're probably in a fragile equilibrium supply-demand.

BARTIROMO: OK.

KAPLAN: You can see a lot of volatility like we've seen, but the fact of the matter is Shell is going to -- is going to need to grow prolifically to keep up with global demand and their limits to how fast Shell can grow.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. OK.

KAPLAN: And so you still may see some price pressure of the upside, but this is why you've seen the short-term downdraft.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now, Former Shell Oil President, John Hofmeister.

Mr. Hofmeister, great to see you. Where do you -- where do you think oil goes from here in the short run?

JOHN HOFMEISTER, FORMER PRESIDENT, SHELL OIL: I think in the short run, it's going to hover around where it is now, Dagen.

I think the waivers on the Iranian sanctions has had a big impact on the traders' mentality as to whether oil is, you know, short or long.

And I -- and I think it's -- there's plenty of oil out there.

I think the Saudis are hard-pressed to really cut production in the aftermath of the Turkey situation.

And I think the Permian Basin has thousands -- not hundreds, but thousands of drill, but uncompleted wells which could come online early next year.

So, I think the -- there's just plenty of supply at the moment.

FREEMAN: John, James Freeman here with The Wall Street Journal. I want to ask you about the Permian. We heard on the show last week that the bottlenecks are largely easing.

Can West Texas producers basically respond and make up for whatever cut the Saudis do manage to persuade on OPEC?

HOFMEISTER: Not in '19, I don't think.

The -- in principle, I agree. The issues, the logistics issues, are being solved with new pipelines, but they're not built yet.

So, they're not in place, but in addition, there are labor shortages that have to be reckoned with and a lot of people are just deferring opportunities in the oil patch for a variety of reasons.

Namely the insecurity that's always been there.

But I do think they will solve those problems and there will be a point at which -- exactly what you said will occur, but I don't think that's in the first half of 2019.

MCDOWELL: Have the steel tariffs cause problems for the pipeline makers?

I know there was some issue about sourcing of the steel used in one particular pipeline.

HOFMEISTER: Well, it's not just the pipeline, it's also the drilling companies or the operating companies because you have all that steel pipe.

And a lot of that pipe has historically come out of China. And so it has played a role, it has increased costs, and, you know, I think people are waiting to see what happens in the larger China-U.S. relationship as to when or how, if ever, that gets fixed.

MCDOWELL: John, so gas prices have been sliding, millions of Americans hitting the roads already for the Thanksgiving holiday.

The current national average is $2.62 a gallon, that's according to AAA, it's about $0.10 higher than the price.

Drivers paid last Thanksgiving, but it's notably lower than gas prices were even a month ago where the average was $2.87.

Does this help consumers? Certainly people pay attention to falling gas prices, but it -- does it really hit them in a positive way?

HOFMEISTER: Well, absolutely. President Trump has had a direct hand in all of this, you know.

With his pressure on Saudi, with his waivers, it has really led to the availability of gasoline.

And if you followed the week-to-week statistics, which I tend to do, we've had a lot of stored oil in the last four to six weeks in the U.S. where storage number have gone up

And refineries haven't really -- haven't really gotten into their shutdown periods yet so they've been producing a lot of gasoline, so I'd say for the next month or two, we probably have plenty of gasoline on the market.

I saw $2.20 a gallon yesterday in Houston.

MCDOWELL: Love it. John Hofmeister.

HOFMEISTER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much for being here. Take care, John. We'll see you soon. Coming up.

HOFMEISTER: You bet.

MCDOWELL: Corruption concerns at General Electric. More dilemmas piling up as the company sinks power sales in Iraq.

We'll tell you more.

And swept away, a skydiver gets snagged in a fence. This weekend's NASCAR, the final race of the year, a full sports roundup.

Who won the championship? He was driving a Ford.

More ahead.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern.

Escalating trade tensions with China, Futures are pointing to a lower open this morning, as investors watch ongoing negotiations between Washington and Beijing. The S&P 500 edging higher on Friday, but it was sleep losses from earlier in the week that pushed all three major market gauges into negative territory on the week.

In Europe, to start a new week is a shortened session this week. The markets closed on Thursday here at home, but we have gains across the board in England, France, and Germany, this Monday. In Asia, markets closing higher overnight. We have gains across the board there.

Retail in focus, L Brands and Target, reporting this week, ahead of Black Friday and the holiday shopping season, we break down the expectations ahead, plus, concerns over General Electric, the shocking report detailing corruption allegations, against key business partners overseas, and YouTube's Hollywood debut, the shifting strategy for the video sharing company ahead.

From the White House to the football field, why Condoleezza Rice says she will not be coaching the Cleveland Browns any time soon, after she was reportedly considered for an interview. And I want to start this rumor, how about running NASCAR, Condoleezza Rice?

We move on to Formula Three, there was a horrible wreck harrowing video from the Macau Grand Prix, leading to a driver who was hospitalized. That car was moving so fast, that we need to really slow that video down, to show you -- she survived that accident. We'll bring you more. We'll bring you an update on her condition, coming up.

To our top story this half hour, financial services regulation, looming, a report from Axios says Congresswoman Maxine Waters is looking to bring oversight of international financial institutions under the umbrella of the House Financial Services Committee. She is set to take over as chair of that committee under the new Congress, when Democrats take control of the House.

Joining me now is Media D.C. Political Analyst Ron Meyer, Ron, always good to see you. What do you make of this report? And what Maxine Waters running that committee, will do to regulation, what the motive would be there?

RON MEYER, POLITICAL ANALYST, MEDIA D.C.: Well, elections have consequences and here you go. This is something Maxine Waters actually have been talking about for quite some time. She's totally going to rearrange the subcommittee structure for this committee.

And what she's going to do is put the regulation, in oversight, of basically foreign banks under the same subcommittee as elicit and illegal activity.

And so, she's already sort of saying hey, a lot of these foreign banks, especially she's really targeting Deutsche Bank because of its relationship 20 plus years ago with President Trump. And so, she wants to bring in all of this into the subcommittee and really try to stir things up.

No one really should be surprised. Everyone new Maxine Waters will be Financial Services Chair. I don't think anybody in business thought it would be particularly good for the marketplace, but here we are. And so, she's laying out his plan, she's trying to get her other committee Democrats on board, and it looks like this is going to advance.

Is it good for the markets? No. Of course, the only issue is she's obviously not going to be able to get anything passed, that will pass the Senate and get the President's signature, but what she can do is a lot of investigations and a lot of subpoenas.

And so, while you wouldn't really think the financial services committee would be a home for investigations. I think that's what we're going to see under Chairman Waters.

MCDOWELL: James, they -- literally, every Democrat sitting on a committee is going to figure out some way to investigate President Trump.

FREEMAN: That's right. And I think for her, the play is going to be looking at his banking relationships, looking at banks that Russia and China use and trying to tie that somehow to the furious action on the President's part.

But Ron, I do wonder, you mentioned none of this legislation that's going to come out of her committee is going to become law, you mentioned the investigative piece. She also has the ability to try to embarrass administration officials in hearings.

Do you think she can move the needle and change regulation based on that pressure on bringing a spotlight to issues she doesn't -- or differences she has with administration regulations?

MEYER: Well, you know, I doubt that she's able to get the President and the Republican Senate to agree to things by doing anything overly dramatic. I do think that there's actually some room on financial services to work across the aisle. And surprisingly, she has some of the history of doing that. And so, if that's where her focus is, I think there could be some productivity there.

But it looks like -- I mean, listen, her whole campaign season, we're talking about going in harassing members of Congress who are Republicans, whether that a restaurant or a public place. I mean, I don't really think she should be the one who should be reaching across aisle, trying to be productive.

I think what she's going to be trying to do is try to stay in the headlines, to try to stay relevant. And frankly, I think it's something that President Trump is welcoming. I think he wants Speaker Pelosi and he wants Chairman Waters.

I think he wants these people to be his opponents and to help rev up his base for 2020. Do I think it's good for our political system, do I think it's good for our markets? Absolutely not, but it's good for President Trump's re-election campaign.

So, I don't think he's particularly sad about it because it is going to gin up the base because they're going to have perfect antagonist to go after.

MCDOWELL: Well, you got into the President did, Lee, a little interesting back and forth with Adam Schiff, over the weekend, which we will not go into because there's a -- anyway -- no, we can't.

CARTER: to start with that fire, but one of my questions right now, I mean, look at, what do you think that we're sacrificing by having the focus shift be more on international, rather than the things that we have been?

And on top of that, I'm really curious, you said that you think that they can compromise or work together and what kinds of things do you think that they can come together on and what would that do for us?

MEYER: Well, Maxine Waters actually worked with Republicans, this last year, on a bipartisan bill that actually lessens regulations on some community banks, and I think there's more work to be done there.

And there are things that Republicans and Democrats can agree on when it comes to fixing regulations and financial services and putting in good, you know, consumer protections. But I think, like I said, I'm not sure that's really going to be her focus with the comments that we've seen come out and the structure that she's putting in place at the subcommittees.

And so, I do think that a large part of her media attention focus will be on these international banks, tying them to Russia and China and President Trump. And what we're going to have unfortunately, I think, is another two years of really chaotic politics.

I think -- I'm not sure that's why Democrats won the House, to be honest with you. I think Democrats won the House to be a check on the crazy politics, right? And instead, they're answering crazy politics with crazy politics, right? And so, I don't think that's -- I don't think that's going to win them the White House in 2020, and I don't think that it's going to increase the majorities in either House.

LI: And it could be bad for business as well, Ron, because --

MEYER: Absolutely.

LI: Yes, think of, you know, Wells Fargo and John Stumpf, I mean, I imagine that a lot more bank CEOs in the future will be hauled, in front of Congress, and probably embarrassed, and asked multiple, multiple questions about some of their questionable business practices, so what does that say for -- what does a message being signalled to bank executives?

MEYER: I mean, she called for Wells Fargo to be broken up.

LI: Right.

MEYER: And so, what does that tell you? I mean, I think a lot of us here have Wells Fargo accounts. Doesn't that make you feel a little uncomfortable? It makes me feel a little uncomfortable. My mortgage is through Wells Fargo. I'm a little uncomfortable.

You know, so I think that many of us who have retirement accounts that do have savings accounts for our kids' college accounts, aren't particularly excited about Chairman Waters regulating financial services.

Even though she doesn't have any legislative authority on her own, the fact that she can change markets just by calling people in front of Congress and her, ranging them, the fact that she can start these investigations and subpoena people, on her own, is rather troubling.

MCDOWELL: They also are always looking two years ahead, Ron, and does that really helped them get re-elected, maybe, maybe not. If you're from a deep blue district perhaps, if you're Maxine Waters, perhaps, but in those purple districts, you got to call that into question.

MEYER: Yes. I think you're looking for mature leadership, I think you're looking for calm leadership, and I think that's why Democrats won House, and I'm not sure that's what they're going to get with Chairman Waters and Speaker Pelosi, and I think that long-term, it'll be good for Republicans to have these two in leadership.

MCDOWELL: I can point you to dozens of preschools across this country that show more maturity than the people who work in Washington. Ron --

MEYER: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, great to see you, Ron Meyer. Coming up, a horror crash in Macau, a teenager, Formula Three driver, survives this devastating crash during the Macau Grand Prix, a full sports round up is coming up. And Hollywood magic, coming to YouTube, video-sharing sites new venture into streaming, free, future link flicks.

MCDOWELL: Saudi Arabia's King Salman, delivering a speech on foreign policy this morning. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Dagen. King Salman bin Abdulaziz, is giving his first public address since the killing of Washington Post columnist, Jamal Khashoggi, after embarking on a nationwide tour with his son, the Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. U.S. lawmakers are renewing calls to condemn the Saudi Kingdom after the CIA concluded the king's, the Saudi prince, ordered Khashoggi's killing. On Fox News Sunday, yesterday, President Trump explained why he won't listen to the tape recording of Khashoggi's murder.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: It's a suffering tape. It is a terrible tape. I've been fully briefed on it. There's no reason for me to hear it. Like I said to the people, should I they said you really shouldn't, there's no reason. I know exactly, I know everything that went on where that happened --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, the crowned prince has continuously denied his involvement in Khashoggi's murder.

Well, General Electric reportedly facing a dilemma in Iraq, as the company seeks power sales. The Wall Street Journal says, the G.E. has learned from a consultant's report about corruption allegations against some of their key business partners in Iraq. The report advises G.E. to distance himself from at least one of its contracts there. G.E. is competing with Germany's Siemens for multi-billion-dollar new power contracts throughout that country. Shares of G.E. are lower in the pre-market, a quarter of a percent right now.

Well YouTube is now streaming full length movies for free. But, of course, there's a catch because nothing is free, right? To enjoy them, you've got to endure advertisements that support the movie. But if you are willing to pay to be a YouTube premium subscriber the ads go away. Movies so far include "Rocky," "Zookeeper," and "Legally Blonde" among other. Shares of Google parent company, Alphabet, which owns YouTube, up about one percent so far this year, Dagen. And there you go, another way to stream content. Like number 50.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I hooked my dad with streaming his ACC games or his University of Virginia games.

CASONE: Nice, that's important.

MCDOWELL: That was a -- that was a long row, so to speak.

CASONE: Yes, the teaching moments with our parents can be interesting sometimes.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl. Coming up, dreams of Coach Condi; why Condoleezza Rice says that she will not be coaching Cleveland Browns. More sports, next.

MCDOWELL: A lot of drama in NFL yesterday. Jared Max is here with all of your sports highlights. Hey, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SPORTS REPORTER: Hey, Dagen. There were three walk off wins on last second field goals by the Broncos, the Cowboys and the Raiders. Last minute comeback went for the Steelers -- how about the Vikings last night? First place, Bears were up 14-0. They were leading 14-6 when Chicago's Eddy Jackson intercepted Kirk Cousins, brought it in for a touchdown. Chicago led 20-6, now, the bear were leading 25-20. Two minutes to go, Minnesota after a touchdown tries an onside kick, but the Bears recovering. Chicago wins, now 7-3 way to off the NFC north.

33 years to the day since legendary Washington Redskins Quarterback Joe Theismann suffered a career-ending injury -- he was at the Skins' game Sunday, where the team's current quarterback, Alex Smith suffered identical injuries that Theismann did. Just as it happened to Joe, Alex Smith taken down near the 40-yard line fractured his right fibula and tibia; he's down for season. From the game, Theismann tweeted: "Alex's leg is exactly like mine. I feel so bad for him." While Theismann by sacked by all-time great Lawrence Taylor, Smith in part by modern-day legend, J.J. Watt, who said: "Thoughts are with Alex. Absolutely gutted about it. Never want to see that for anyone ever. Wishing you all the best brother." Like the Theismann game, final score yesterday, 23-21. Same thing but this time, the Redskins lost.

Hey, did you catch that ESPN report yesterday that said the Cleveland Browns were going to interview former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice for their head coaching job. It's not actually happening. The Browns said, she's not on the radar and the Madame Secretary confirmed it. Though, she said she would like to get to call a couple of plates for Browns, and open doors for women in coaching.

Watch this Formula 3 crash, at 171 miles per hour. 17-year-old German, Sophia Floersch, fractured her spine, fractured a facial bone, suffered concussion and other lacerations; 170 miles per hour at the Macau Grand Prix in China. She says, I'm fine but will go into surgery tomorrow. NASCAR Monster Energy Cup Series championship, Homestead, Miami, 12 laps to go -- oh, well, this is actually before the race. The parachuter got caught in the catch fence. Late in the race, 12 laps to go. Joey Logano, who made it to the final, two of the previous three years, finally wins it. He passes Martin Truex Jr., and Logano gets the big win for Roger Penske Racing.

MCDOWELL: Roger Penske is an icon, obviously, that was a Ford win. The -- that's a Ford car. By the way, I watched it. Not the biggest Logano fan; it was Kevin Harvick, Martin Truex Jr., Kyle Busch and then Lagano for the win. Martin Truex Jr. racing for furniture row, this ends furniture row racing. (INAUDIBLE) and Jimmy Johnson will no longer be the crew chief and driver team, and (INAUDIBLE) has gone off Jimmy Johnson's car -- and A.J. (INAUDIBLE) leaves the series, in case you were interested in any of that.

MAX: Well, I know that Lee is going to repeat that all back to you in alphabetical order.

CARTER: I am, but I have to watch it a few times.

MCDOWELL: Did you watch the race, Jared.

MAX: Dagen, I was watching football all day, I switched over just before Logano took the lead at 12 laps to go and this is great. Saw everything I needed to see.

MCDOWELL: What did you watch sports wise yesterday?

FREEMAN: Well, I was watching a lot of kids sports this weekend. And -- sadly our fifth graders lost in the Super Bowl, but they will be back next year.

MCDOWELL: But that was horrific injury for the Redskins.

MAX: Medical -- things have changed so much. Alex Smith, let's hope he gets to come back from this. That was a career-ender for Joe Theismann.

CARTER: 30 years ago.

MAX: 33 years ago to the day, that it was the same score that had happened near the 40-yard line, the same thing that a legendary defensive player caused the injury in part on the sack.

MCDOWELL: Who looks good, team wise, in the NFL right now?

MAX: Tonight game; 2-9-1 (INAUDIBLE) -- that could be a possible super bowl preview, the Saints, though. Yesterday they destroyed --

MCDOWELL: Crushed!

MAX: They crushed the Eagles. That they've scored 40 points or more in six game this is season, that ties an NFL record. They look like the team to beat at this moment.

CARTER: Why can't Condi be the head coach of the Browns? I think that would be a great choice.

MAX: Well, she was saying on Facebook, that's not actually what, you know, she wanted.

CARTER: I want to know where that rumor started.

MCDOWELL: Well, she could run the NFL: That's long been -- shoot. Condi Rice could run NASCAR. I nominate Condi Rice to run NASCAR. There you go.

MAX: You heard it from her first.

MCDOWELL: They're trying to -- they're trying to sell it. Again, icon, I don't know -- if she likes motor sports but it's an idea. And flying the flight for female leadership, and I encourage everyone I listen to the Rae Carruth podcast done by Charlotte observer and Scott Fowley, it is one of the most moving things you'll ever listen to for Sandra Adams, and (INAUDIBLE) Adams. I'll just believe it at that but Rae Carruth is out of prison now. Listen to this. It's incredible reporting and if you are -- if you followed that story at all --

MAX: It's fascinating.

MCDOWELL: It's fascinating. It's like a seven-part series. So --

MAX: I didn't want to come see him in prison and then now they're -- and he has cerebral palsy and so he's being race by his grandmother. It's a story of triumph and forgiveness and love. I'm just -- I'm not going to give it all away.

CARTER: And I can't believe it's been how many years now, over 20 years?

MCDOWELL: 99 is when she Surekha was murdered. Thank you so much, Jared. Sports Reports Fox New Headlines 24/7, SiriusXM 155. Still ahead, Christmas is coming to the White House. The tree will arrive in Washington later today. Next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

MCDOWELL: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th, your top story at 7:00 a.m. Eastern. Rising trade tensions with China. Vice President Mike Pence back from the Asia Pacific summit without an accord. Now, the focus shifts to the g-20 summit next week where President Trump is set to meet with China's President Xi.

The futures are under this pressure this morning, coming off a week of losses, and 85-point loss on the Dow Futures. The selling picking up a little bit of steam as we move closer to the opening bell a little more than two and-a-half hours from now. This after a --

Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

And a magical weekend at the box office, the Fantastic Beasts sequel duking it out with The Grinch in theaters. We'll tell you who took the top spot.

All that and so much more coming up this morning.

Our very own Susan Li from the Fox Business Network. "The Wall Street Journal" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: So it was James talking before the show started on Florida's settle. We got Griff Jenkins coming up in about six, seven minutes from now with a hit from Florida.

MCDOWELL: I can point you to dozens of preschools across this country that show more maturity than the people who work in Washington. Ron --

MEYER: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, great to see you, Ron Meyer. Coming up, a horror crash in Macau, a teenager, Formula Three driver, survives this devastating crash during the Macau Grand Prix, a full sports round up is coming up. And Hollywood magic, coming to YouTube, video-sharing sites new venture into streaming, free, future link flicks.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Saudi Arabia's King Salman, delivering a speech on foreign policy this morning. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Dagen. King Salman bin Abdulaziz, is giving his first public address since the killing of Washington Post columnist, Jamal Khashoggi, after embarking on a nationwide tour with his son, the Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. U.S. lawmakers are renewing calls to condemn the Saudi Kingdom after the CIA concluded the king's, the Saudi prince, ordered Khashoggi's killing. On Fox News Sunday, yesterday, President Trump explained why he won't listen to the tape recording of Khashoggi's murder.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: It's a suffering tape. It is a terrible tape. I've been fully briefed on it. There's no reason for me to hear it. Like I said to the people, should I they said you really shouldn't, there's no reason. I know exactly, I know everything that went on where that happened --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, the crowned prince has continuously denied his involvement in Khashoggi's murder.

Well, General Electric reportedly facing a dilemma in Iraq, as the company seeks power sales. The Wall Street Journal says, the G.E. has learned from a consultant's report about corruption allegations against some of their key business partners in Iraq. The report advises G.E. to distance himself from at least one of its contracts there. G.E. is competing with Germany's Siemens for multi-billion-dollar new power contracts throughout that country. Shares of G.E. are lower in the pre-market, a quarter of a percent right now.

Well YouTube is now streaming full length movies for free. But, of course, there's a catch because nothing is free, right? To enjoy them, you've got to endure advertisements that support the movie. But if you are willing to pay to be a YouTube premium subscriber the ads go away. Movies so far include "Rocky," "Zookeeper," and "Legally Blonde" among other. Shares of Google parent company, Alphabet, which owns YouTube, up about one percent so far this year, Dagen. And there you go, another way to stream content. Like number 50.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I hooked my dad with streaming his ACC games or his University of Virginia games.

CASONE: Nice, that's important.

MCDOWELL: That was a -- that was a long row, so to speak.

CASONE: Yes, the teaching moments with our parents can be interesting sometimes.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl. Coming up, dreams of Coach Condi; why Condoleezza Rice says that she will not be coaching Cleveland Browns. More sports, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A lot of drama in NFL yesterday. Jared Max is here with all of your sports highlights. Hey, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SPORTS REPORTER: Hey, Dagen. There were three walk off wins on last second field goals by the Broncos, the Cowboys and the Raiders. Last minute comeback went for the Steelers -- how about the Vikings last night? First place, Bears were up 14-0. They were leading 14-6 when Chicago's Eddy Jackson intercepted Kirk Cousins, brought it in for a touchdown. Chicago led 20-6, now, the bear were leading 25-20. Two minutes to go, Minnesota after a touchdown tries an onside kick, but the Bears recovering. Chicago wins, now 7-3 way to off the NFC north.

33 years to the day since legendary Washington Redskins Quarterback Joe Theismann suffered a career-ending injury -- he was at the Skins' game Sunday, where the team's current quarterback, Alex Smith suffered identical injuries that Theismann did. Just as it happened to Joe, Alex Smith taken down near the 40-yard line fractured his right fibula and tibia; he's down for season. From the game, Theismann tweeted: "Alex's leg is exactly like mine. I feel so bad for him." While Theismann by sacked by all-time great Lawrence Taylor, Smith in part by modern-day legend, J.J. Watt, who said: "Thoughts are with Alex. Absolutely gutted about it. Never want to see that for anyone ever. Wishing you all the best brother." Like the Theismann game, final score yesterday, 23-21. Same thing but this time, the Redskins lost.

Hey, did you catch that ESPN report yesterday that said the Cleveland Browns were going to interview former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice for their head coaching job. It's not actually happening. The Browns said, she's not on the radar and the Madame Secretary confirmed it. Though, she said she would like to get to call a couple of plates for Browns, and open doors for women in coaching.

Watch this Formula 3 crash, at 171 miles per hour. 17-year-old German, Sophia Floersch, fractured her spine, fractured a facial bone, suffered concussion and other lacerations; 170 miles per hour at the Macau Grand Prix in China. She says, I'm fine but will go into surgery tomorrow. NASCAR Monster Energy Cup Series championship, Homestead, Miami, 12 laps to go -- oh, well, this is actually before the race. The parachuter got caught in the catch fence. Late in the race, 12 laps to go. Joey Logano, who made it to the final, two of the previous three years, finally wins it. He passes Martin Truex Jr., and Logano gets the big win for Roger Penske Racing.

MCDOWELL: Roger Penske is an icon, obviously, that was a Ford win. The -- that's a Ford car. By the way, I watched it. Not the biggest Logano fan; it was Kevin Harvick, Martin Truex Jr., Kyle Busch and then Lagano for the win. Martin Truex Jr. racing for furniture row, this ends furniture row racing. (INAUDIBLE) and Jimmy Johnson will no longer be the crew chief and driver team, and (INAUDIBLE) has gone off Jimmy Johnson's car -- and A.J. (INAUDIBLE) leaves the series, in case you were interested in any of that.

MAX: Well, I know that Lee is going to repeat that all back to you in alphabetical order.

CARTER: I am, but I have to watch it a few times.

MCDOWELL: Did you watch the race, Jared.

MAX: Dagen, I was watching football all day, I switched over just before Logano took the lead at 12 laps to go and this is great. Saw everything I needed to see.

MCDOWELL: What did you watch sports wise yesterday?

FREEMAN: Well, I was watching a lot of kids sports this weekend. And -- sadly our fifth graders lost in the Super Bowl, but they will be back next year.

MCDOWELL: But that was horrific injury for the Redskins.

MAX: Medical -- things have changed so much. Alex Smith, let's hope he gets to come back from this. That was a career-ender for Joe Theismann.

CARTER: 30 years ago.

MAX: 33 years ago to the day, that it was the same score that had happened near the 40-yard line, the same thing that a legendary defensive player caused the injury in part on the sack.

MCDOWELL: Who looks good, team wise, in the NFL right now?

MAX: Tonight game; 2-9-1 (INAUDIBLE) -- that could be a possible super bowl preview, the Saints, though. Yesterday they destroyed --

MCDOWELL: Crushed!

MAX: They crushed the Eagles. That they've scored 40 points or more in six game this is season, that ties an NFL record. They look like the team to beat at this moment.

CARTER: Why can't Condi be the head coach of the Browns? I think that would be a great choice.

MAX: Well, she was saying on Facebook, that's not actually what, you know, she wanted.

CARTER: I want to know where that rumor started.

MCDOWELL: Well, she could run the NFL: That's long been -- shoot. Condi Rice could run NASCAR. I nominate Condi Rice to run NASCAR. There you go.

MAX: You heard it from her first.

MCDOWELL: They're trying to -- they're trying to sell it. Again, icon, I don't know -- if she likes motor sports but it's an idea. And flying the flight for female leadership, and I encourage everyone I listen to the Rae Carruth podcast done by Charlotte observer and Scott Fowley, it is one of the most moving things you'll ever listen to for Sandra Adams, and (INAUDIBLE) Adams. I'll just believe it at that but Rae Carruth is out of prison now. Listen to this. It's incredible reporting and if you are -- if you followed that story at all --

MAX: It's fascinating.

MCDOWELL: It's fascinating. It's like a seven-part series. So --

MAX: I didn't want to come see him in prison and then now they're -- and he has cerebral palsy and so he's being race by his grandmother. It's a story of triumph and forgiveness and love. I'm just -- I'm not going to give it all away.

CARTER: And I can't believe it's been how many years now, over 20 years?

MCDOWELL: 99 is when she Surekha was murdered. Thank you so much, Jared. Sports Reports Fox New Headlines 24/7, SiriusXM 155. Still ahead, Christmas is coming to the White House. The tree will arrive in Washington later today. Next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th, your top story at 7:00 a.m. Eastern. Rising trade tensions with China. Vice President Mike Pence back from the Asia Pacific summit without an accord. Now, the focus shifts to the g-20 summit next week where President Trump is set to meet with China's President Xi.

The futures are under this pressure this morning, coming off a week of losses, and 85-point loss on the Dow Futures. The selling picking up a little bit of steam as we move closer to the opening bell a little more than two and-a-half hours from now. This after a --

END
