urn:contentItem:5TSP-K701-JBHT-D2P8-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In Race2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations is 'Inevitable'; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; RPT: Nissan's Carlos Ghosn Under Arrest; Search for Common Ground at the White House Ahead of New Leadership; Rep. Maxine Waters Targets Global Banks with Financial Services Stir; Saudi King Salman Speech; G.E. Power Sales In Iraq; Alex Smith's Brutal Injury; Condoleezza Not Coaching; 17-year-old Crashes In RaceLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Good to see you Cheryl and Lauren. I'll see you both.

If you hear people talking, guess what we're talking about? Everything's settled in Florida. That's one of the top stories that we will get to this morning.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at the 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Tough times for Apple. CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation, but he says it is coming. And the tech giant unite is already struggling with orders for its new phone and suppliers are paying the price.

We break it all down.

Meantime, futures are showing weakness across the board. A 48-point loss on the Dow Futures right now, as we move into, or begin this shortened holiday week, this after a week of red for all the major market indicators.

The Dow and NASDAQ both off more than two percent last week. The S&P 500 shedding 1.6 percent.

In Europe, to start this week, we have gains across the board, although slight but green in England, France, and Germany.

In Asian markets, finishing higher overnight as well. No red in Asia. The biggest winner there, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Nevertheless, trade tensions with China on the rise. Vice President Mike Pence returning from the Asia Pacific Summit without a communique, without an accord.

Now the focus shifts to the G20 where President Trump is set to meet with President Xi next week, but President Trump speaking out about the difficulty of coming to an agreement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China wants to make a deal. They sent a list of things that they're willing to do, which was a large list, and just not acceptable to me yet.

But at some point, I think that we are doing extremely well with respect to China. I have a great respect for President Xi, I have a great respect for China.

But China has taken advantage of the United States for many, many years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We look at what is at stake straight ahead.

And breaking news on Nissan, trouble for the automaker. The company looking to remove Chairman, Carlos Ghosn.

Japan's NHK news service reporting that Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. We will dig into that story.

And a magical weekend at the box office, the Fantastic Beasts sequel duking it out with The Grinch in theaters. We'll tell you who took the top spot.

All that and so much more coming up this morning.

Our very own Susan Li from the Fox Business Network. "The Wall Street Journal" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

MCDOWELL: So it was James talking before the show started on Florida's settle. We got Griff Jenkins coming up in about six, seven minutes from now with a hit from Florida.

Close call election, the Editorial Page wrote about it this morning, but Rick Scott is the Senator from Florida.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right. So that's a Republican pick up.

And I think good for the country that the losers in that race have now conceded. You hate to have a replay of that 2000 drama where it becomes a battle of lawyers.

And this one, fortunately, was decided by voters.

MCDOWELL: Right. And also -- but it does kind of set the stage for two years from now. Can Florida get its act together?

FREEMAN: Yes. I -- this has been going on forever. You look at especially in Palm Beach, I think 2002, '04, '06, 2016, and then earlier this summer with the primary continuing problems following the law.

And I would say high-time for the state government to prioritize performance or --

MCDOWELL: And there is, and we'll get to this as well, but the Broward Country Election Chief, there's -- there are reports out there that Brenda Snipes has resigned amid the recount effort down in Florida.

So we will discuss that. I'll give you a breath to let you collect your thoughts.

FREEMAN: Yes. You know, I think what you want is maybe some legislation at the state level as well because you recall Snipes' predecessor wasn't so hot either, got fired for similar problems.

So, I think you need some kind of standard.

MCDOWELL: She was initially selected by Governor Jeb Bush in --

FREEMAN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- in the early 2000s.

So we'll get -- we'll get into that whole story, but we want to get to -- he said regulation, but we're talking about a different type of regulation.

Coming to big tech, Apple CEO Tim Cook issuing a warning on what he believes to be the inevitable arrival of regulation in Silicon Valley.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: Generally speaking, I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market, but we have to admit when the free market's not working and it hasn't worked here.

And I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Susan, your reaction to that.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I would say it's easy for Tim Cook to say, isn't it? Because he doesn't deal when it comes to data as other people like the Facebook and social media players.

So, some would say that he's probably able to lob stones at glasshouses at this point, and, you know, with him looking at regulation over social media, doesn't that help his position as well?

Doesn't it strengthen Apple at this point? So, I think it's easy for him to say.

MCDOWELL: They've used that certainly as a marketing too, James, but what do you make of this? Because, again, it's possible -- we've talked about this for -- literally I've been talking about it for years, that they need to come up with some sort of self-regulatory system within technology.

But now that you've had these -- Facebook, Google, falling flat on their face, not doing a great job if they even decided to show up in front of Congress that this is a really tricky situation that technology companies are facing.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think Susan raises a great question, is -- I think consumers should be very skeptical here. Is this a play where he thinks his business model will do better under regulation --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

FREEMAN: -- than say a Facebook or a Google that Apple competes with in some arenas?

Yes, Apple has a services business, but they are a hardware company, maybe he sees an advantage.

I just -- I just think this statement that this is a market failure, first of all, markets don't have to work perfectly, they just have to work better than government.

And second of all --

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- people want free services. So, to say it's a failure that people have tolerated years and years of trading personal information for lots of services, I is a mistake.

I think people, for better or worse, have enjoyed a lot of the free stuff they've gotten from Silicon Valley, and, you know, maybe they'd like a different trade.

But I don't think that government --- I'd be very worried about a government program that ends up advantaging incumbents, like Apple, as it - -

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: -- usually does and prevents new competitor.

MCDOWELL: Well, I had this conversation with someone who works in the technology industry over the last five years days or so about the New York Times article about Facebook.

And the individual's response was, "Grab a drink. Welcome to the party."

LI: Yes, it's not --

MCDOWELL: "Where have you been the last -- "

LI: Not a surprise for anybody, really.

MCDOWELL: " -- the last 10 years of Facebook's life, literally.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That Facebook -- if you used Facebook over the years, they constantly ask you for more and more and more granular personal information about yourself.

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And then you sit and go, "Wow, it's free."

LI: Well, I mean there's a -- there's a great article in "The Wall Street Journal" over the weekend.

FREEMAN: You're (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: What do you think is happening?

LI: Yes, that says basically the reason Instagram founders left is because Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg, he wanted to extract more information from you for -- from Instagram.

They wanted to know your location and the Instagram founders are like, "Whoa, whoa, whoa, this is not what we signed up for."

But I think inevitability, that is the -- basically the signal from all of tech.

I was at the Laguna Beach, WSJ --

MCDOWELL: Right. Right.

LI: -- D Live event and --

FREEMAN: Uh-hmm.

LI: -- everybody understands that this is a new reality.

CARTER: Right.

LI: If you don't, if you're not prepared for it, you shouldn't be CEO.

CARTER: But I also think that, you know, if you look at what's happening in Europe, too, a lot of people are saying, "You know what, with privacy, with all of these kinds of concerns out there, we're going that way. We better be prepared for it."

And Tim Cook is in a unique position to talk about privacy because let's not forget, Apple has had a hard line on what privacy means and how you're not going to access anything that's on there, you know, on there.

So I think they think this is going to make them more popular because they are all about privacy and everybody else in social media maybe isn't, so.

LI: I don't know that they're all about privacy willingly, let's just put it that way.

But I think they see this as a -- probably a position of strength that they're in right now.

MCDOWELL: She's referring to the Apple -- and I was very critical of Apple pushing back on the FBI when --

LI: San Bernardino?

MCDOWELL: Yes, when the FBI wanted Apple to help. Essentially right code so they could access the -- one of the terrorists, the murderer's phones and Apple pushed back on that in the courts.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And I was critical of them, but again that was the line.

And this is really -- this is a stance that Steve Jobs took from the very beginning.

But these are different -- they are different businesses.

CARTER: Very different.

MCDOWELL: Facebook and Google are different -- well, Google, to a lesser extent --

LI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: -- because of the Android operating system.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And they're in the device business indirectly, but again, it's - - Tim Cook is throwing some shade.

urn:contentItem:5TDG-SH21-JBYT-H256-00000-00Apple CEO Tim Cook says that it's a 'challenge' getting Congress up to speed on the need for new privacy regulations2018-10-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:14:06ZLexisNexisApple CEO Tim Cook says that it's a 'challenge' getting Congress up to speed on the need for new privacy regulationsNew Delhi

New Delhi, Oct. 03 -- Apple CEO Tim Cook is reiterating his call for new government regulations to protect consumer privacy from tech companies.
The amount of information about individual users stored online and on their phones is enormous, Cook said in an interview with Vice News Tonight on Tuesday. The tech industry hasn't done a good job of respecting and protecting that data, he said. "I'm not a pro-regulation kind of person, I believe in the free market deeply," Cook said. But, he added, "when the free market doesn't produce a result that's great for society, you have to ask yourself: what do we need to do? And I think some level of government regulation is important to come out of that."


Despite advocating for new regulations, Cook, who has repeatedly advocated new privacy rules this year, expressed doubt whether Congress is as up to speed on technology as it would need to be to craft beneficial legislation in the area. The technology "literacy" of legislators and their staffs is "a challenge," he said.
"There is a need to work with Congress and the staff to make sure that we do our jobs of helping them kind of come up to speed on ... on what's possible," he said.
Consumer advocates, policy makers, and tech industry figures have been increasingly discussing the need for new privacy regulations, particularly in the wake of Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal this spring. In that incident, some 87 million customer records were leaked to a data analysis firm linked to President Donald Trump. More recently, Facebook acknowledged that at least 50 million accounts were compromised thanks to a security hole. Cook doesn't think Apple will change its privacy stance
Apple and Cook have repeatedly tried to distinguish the company from its Big Tech peers such as Facebook and Google. Unlike those companies, Apple's business isn't built around advertising revenue or collecting scads of data on its users to target them with ads. Apple actually tries to limit the amount of information it collects on users, Cook said.
"The way we go into product design, we challenge ourselves to collect as little as possible," he said. He continued: "You are not our product." Some in the industry have asserted that Apple's restraint in data collection will ultimately hurt the company's ability to compete with its rivals, particularly in areas such as artificial intelligence and machine learning. Those technologies tend to improve as they get access to more data. An intelligent assistant, for example, could potentially offer more useful suggestions about what restaurant a user might like if it had more information about what restaurants they've liked in the past.
But Cook disputed the notion that Apple itself needs to collect more data on users to improve it services, suggesting instead that users' devices could collect it instead - without sharing it with the company.
"The narrative that some companies will try to get you to believe is 'I've got to take all of your data to make my service better.' Well, don't believe that," he said. "Whoever's telling you that - it's a bunch of bonk. We try to keep as much of your information on that device as possible because we want that device to know, because you count on the device to be smart for you."
Some consumer advocates have raised the concern that while Apple may respect user privacy now, things could change under Cook's successors. Users' iPhones collect plenty of data and the company at some point in the future could choose to start collecting it for itself.
But Cook disputed that notion too, saying it would go against Apple's culture.
"I think the next person [who runs Apple], I don't want to commit them, but I can't imagine it. It's not in my imagination that somebody would just say 'oh, time to change,'" he said. I don't see it."
